On 28 January 2011, they accepted a €26.5 million ([[Pound sterling|£]]22.8 million) offer for Suárez from [[Premier League]] club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref name="Echo 2-4"/><ref name="BBCLiverpool">{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/9377256.stm |title=Liverpool land Luis Suarez in £22.7m deal with Ajax |work=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Despite leaving while suspended, Suárez departed Ajax on good terms, and he was given a farewell sendoff after an Ajax match. During the sendoff, an Ajax coach spoke to him and the crowd and said how the club wished he could stay longer; the crowd applauded their agreement and fireworks followed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ajax.nl/News/Archive/Article/Jubilant-farewell-Suarez.htm |title=Jubilant farewell Suarez |work=Ajax.nl |publisher=AFC Ajax |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=26 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110224224341/http://english.ajax.nl/News/Archive/Article/Jubilant-farewell-Suarez.htm |archivedate=24 February 2011 |df= }}</ref> Ajax ended the [[2010–11 Eredivisie|2010–11 season]] as Eredivisie champions<ref>{{cite web |url= http://soccernet.espn.go.com/tables/_/league/ned.1/season/2010/dutch-eredivisie |title= 2010/11 Dutch Eredivisie Table / Standings |publisher= ESPN Soccernet |year= 2011 |accessdate=27 August 2011}}</ref> and Suárez was given a winner's medal<ref name="football database"/><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/jun/01/the-knowledge-football-religious-groups |title= Football teams for religion |first= Barry |last=Glendenning |work= guardian.co.uk |date= 1 June 2011 |accessdate=27 August 2011}}</ref> for his 7 goals in 13 appearances.<ref name="Voetbal">{{cite web|url=http://www.vi.nl/Spelers/Speler/Luis-Surez.htm |title=Luis Suárez Statistics |accessdate=13 April 2010 |publisher=Voetbal International |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325124025/http://www.vi.nl/Spelers/Speler/Luis-Surez.htm |archivedate=25 March 2010 }}</ref> While he was at Ajax, Suárez scored 111 goals in 159 appearances.<ref name="Ajax departure summary"/><ref name="Echo 2-4"/>
===Liverpool=== ====2010–11 season==== [[File:Suarez and Carroll crop.jpg|thumb|Suárez (left) was signed by Liverpool on the same day as [[Andy Carroll]]]] On 31 January 2011, Suárez signed a five-and-a-half-year deal with Liverpool until 2016,<ref name="Echo 2-4"/><ref>{{cite news |first=Elliot |last=Ball |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_6715190,00.html |title=Suarez seals Reds switch |publisher=Sky Sports |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> and was the club's most expensive signing (£22.8 million) until the arrival of [[Andy Carroll]] (£35 million) a few hours later.<ref name="Stoke debut">{{cite news |url= http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2011/02/02/luis-suarez-nets-on-liverpool-fc-debut-100252-28106136/ |title= Luis Suarez nets on Liverpool FC debut |work= Liverpool Echo |publisher=Trinity Mirror |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=27 August 2011}}</ref> Suárez requested the number seven shirt, but at the time did not realise that it had been worn by Liverpool legends such as his new manager [[Kenny Dalglish]] and [[Kevin Keegan]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2011/01/31/liverpool-fc-hand-luis-suarez-anfield-s-famous-no7-shirt-100252-28087283/ |title= Liverpool FC hand Luis Suarez Anfield's famous No7 shirt |first= Neil |last=Jones |work= Liverpool Echo |date= 31 January 2011 |accessdate=26 August 2011}}</ref> Suárez made his Liverpool debut on 2 February against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] at [[Anfield]] in a 2–0 win; he came on as a substitute and scored Liverpool's second goal in front of the [[Spion Kop (stadiums)|Kop]] in the 79th minute.<ref name="Stoke debut"/><ref>{{cite news |first=Mandeep |last=Sanghera |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9378729.stm |title=Liverpool 2–0 Stoke |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> He was one of Liverpool's best players during his partial season<ref name="Hytner">{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/may/09/fulham-liverpool-premier-league |title= Luis Suárez steals the show as Liverpool thrash Fulham |last= Hytner |first=David |work=The Guardian |location=London |date= 10 May 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2011/08/11/liverpool-fc-season-preview-2011-12-lfc-start-to-bridge-the-gap-on-their-rivals-at-the-top-of-the-premier-league-92534-29216966/2/ |title= Liverpool FC season preview 2011/12 – LFC start to bridge the gap on their rivals at the top of the Premier League |last=Doyle |first=Ian |work=Liverpool Daily Post |publisher=Trinity Mirror |page=2 |date= 11 August 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref><ref name="Times of India">{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/epl/epl-news/Uruguay-striker-Suarez-inspiring-Liverpool-revival/articleshow/9679210.cms|title= Uruguay striker Suarez inspiring Liverpool revival |agency= Associated Press |work= The Times of India |date= 21 August 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2014}}</ref> and helped Liverpool go from 12th in the league in mid-January<ref name="Hytner"/> to finish sixth.<ref name="Times of India"/> He finished the [[2010–11 Premier League|2010–11 season]] with four goals in 13 games.<ref name="Voetbal"/>
====2011–12 season==== After winning the Player of the Tournament at the [[2011 Copa América]],<ref name="CopaAmerica"/> Suárez had a disappointing [[2011–12 Premier League|2011–12]] season by his standards.<ref name="Pearce2011-12">{{cite news |url= http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-fc/lfc-player-profiles/luis-suarez/2012/05/19/james-pearce-s-review-of-liverpool-fc-s-2011-12-season-100252-31000189/3/ |title= James Pearce's review of Liverpool FC's 2011/12 season |last= Pearce |first= James |newspaper= Liverpool Echo |page=3 |date= 19 May 2012 |accessdate= 26 June 2012}}</ref> Liverpool finished in eighth place and Suárez scored 11 league goals.<ref name="Pearce2011-12"/> On 26 February, Liverpool won the [[2011–12 Football League Cup|League Cup]], defeating [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in penalty shootout.<ref name="Bevan">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17093419 |title= Cardiff 2–2 Liverpool |work=BBC Sport |date=26 February 2012 |accessdate= 26 June 2012 |first= Chris |last=Bevan}}</ref> On 28 April, Suárez scored his first Liverpool [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|hat-trick]] in 3–0 win against [[Norwich City F.C|Norwich City]] at [[Carrow Road]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17796316 |title=Norwich 0 Liverpool 3 |first= Arindam |last=Rej |work=BBC Sport |date=28 April 2012 |accessdate= 26 June 2012}}</ref> He finished sixth for the [[2011 FIFA Ballon d'Or]].<ref name="votingresults">{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/classic/awards/01/56/60/64/voting_results_ok.pdf |title=FIFA Ballon d'Or 2011 – voting results |work=FIFA.com |date= 9 January 2012 |accessdate=10 January 2012}}</ref>
====Racial abuse incident==== The season was marked by an incident in which Suárez was found guilty by a three-man panel from [[The Football Association]] (FA) of racially abusing [[Patrice Evra]] during a match against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in October; he was issued an eight-match suspension and a £40,000 fine.<ref name="racialguilt">{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/16186556.stm |title=Liverpool striker Luis Suarez handed eight-match FA ban |work=BBC Sport |date=20 December 2011 |accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref> Suárez disputed this decision.<ref name="Suarez statement">{{cite news|last=Suárez |first=Luis |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/statement-from-luis-suarez |title=Statement from Luis Suarez |publisher=Liverpool FC Official Website |date=3 January 2012 |accessdate=25 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219135306/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/statement-from-luis-suarez |archivedate=19 February 2015 |df= }}</ref>
After a 1–1 draw against Manchester United on 15 October 2011, Suárez was accused of racially abusing Evra,<ref name="FA Evra">{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15324927.stm |title= The FA will look into claims Luis Suárez racially abused Patrice Evra |publisher=BBC Sport|date= 16 October 2011 |accessdate=16 October 2011}}</ref> and the FA opened up an investigation into the incident.<ref name="FA Evra"/> Suárez wrote on his [[Twitter]] and Facebook pages that he was upset by the accusation and denied the claims.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/15328769.stm |title= Liverpool's Luis Suárez 'upset' by Patrice Evra's racism claim |publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 October 2011 |accessdate=16 October 2011}}</ref> On 16 November, the FA announced it would charge Suárez with "abusive and/or insulting words and/or behaviour contrary to FA rules", including "a reference to the ethnic origin and/or colour and/or race of Patrice Evra". Liverpool later released a statement announcing Suárez would plead innocent, adding they would "remain fully supportive" of him.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/nov/16/luis-suarez-liverpool-fa-racism |title=Liverpool's Luis Suárez will plead not guilty to FA racism charge |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=16 November 2011 |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |accessdate=17 November 2011}}</ref> On 20 December, the FA concluded a seven-day hearing, handing Suárez an eight-match ban and a £40,000 fine for racially abusing Evra.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/16186556.stm|title=Liverpool striker Luis Suarez handed eight-match FA ban |work=BBC Sport |date=20 December 2011 |accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Sir Alex Ferguson feels ban for Luis Suarez was right |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/16325493.stm |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=1 January 2012|date=24 December 2011}}</ref><ref name="RaceGuard">{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Richard |title=Liverpool should take heed of the past and accept Luis Suárez verdict |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2011/dec/21/luis-suarez-liverpool-racism-fight |publisher=Guardian News and Media |work=The Guardian |accessdate=1 January 2012|date=21 December 2011}}</ref>
In their next meeting in February, during the pregame handshakes, Suárez avoided shaking Evra's hand, for which Suárez and Dalglish were later forced to apologise.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17004667 |work=BBC Sport |title= Luis Suarez and Kenny Dalglish apologise after US owners intervene over handshake row |last= Roan |first= Dan |date=12 February 2012 |accessdate= 12 February 2012}}</ref> Suárez was also banned for one match for [[Finger (gesture)|making an obscene gesture]] towards [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] fans.<ref>{{cite news |title=Luis Suarez admits misconduct charge after gesture|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/16148570 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |accessdate=25 June 2014 |date=28 December 2011}}</ref>
====2012–13 season==== On 7 August 2012, Suárez signed a new long-term contract with Liverpool.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/suarez-signs-new-contract |publisher=Liverpool official website |title=Suarez signs new contract |date=7 August 2012 |accessdate=7 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120810020201/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/suarez-signs-new-contract |archivedate=10 August 2012 |df= }}</ref> On 26 August, he scored his first goal of the [[2012–13 Liverpool F.C. season|2012–13 season]] in a 2–2 draw with champions [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] at Anfield.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19310450|title=Liverpool 2 2 Man City |date=26 August 2012 |accessdate=8 August 2013 |work=BBC}}</ref> On 29 September 2012, Suárez scored a hat-trick in Liverpool's Premier League fixture away at [[Norwich City F.C|Norwich City]] for the second consecutive season.<ref>{{cite web |title=Norwich 2 – 5 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19684133|work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |accessdate=29 September 2012 |date=29 September 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Luis Suarez vs Arsenal (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Suárez playing for Liverpool against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in January 2013]] On 6 January 2013, Suárez handled the ball before scoring the decisive goal in Liverpool's 2–1 win over [[Mansfield Town F.C.|Mansfield Town]] from the [[Conference National]] in an [[2012–13 FA Cup|FA Cup]] third round match. Liverpool's manager [[Brendan Rodgers]] defended his player by claiming "it's not his job to own up", while Mansfield manager [[Paul Cox (footballer)|Paul Cox]] said he felt "a little bit gutted" by the "instinctive" handball, but admitted he would have accepted a goal scored like that by one of his players.<ref>{{cite news |title=Luis Suárez: 'It's not his job to own up' says Brendan Rodgers |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/jan/06/liverpool-brendan-rodgers-luis-suarez-mansfield |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=19 January 2013 |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |date=6 January 2013}}</ref>
On 19 January, Suárez scored his seventh goal in three matches against Norwich, as Liverpool cruised to a 5–0 home league victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/1305262/luis-suarez-extends-reign-in-liverpool-reds'-rout-of-norwich |title=Luis Suarez fuel Liverpool's 5–0 romp |publisher=ESPNFC |date=19 January 2013 }}</ref> The following week, Suárez captained Liverpool for the first time for the FA Cup fourth round match against [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]]; Liverpool lost 2–3.<ref>{{cite web|title=Liverpool FC Match Centre – Oldham v Liverpool |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/match/last-match/match-centre |publisher=[[Liverpool F.C.]] |accessdate=29 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E25xqAX7?url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/match/last-match/match-centre |archivedate=29 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> On 2 March, Suárez scored a hat-trick against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]], leading Liverpool to a dominant 4–0 victory at the [[DW Stadium]]. In so doing, he became only the third Liverpool player to score 20 Premier League goals in a single season after [[Robbie Fowler]] and [[Fernando Torres]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21556751 |title= Wigan 0 Liverpool 4:Luis Suarez scored a hat-trick as Liverpool thrashed Wigan and boosted their hopes of European qualification.|work=BBC Sport |date=3 March 2013 |accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> On 10 March, Suárez scored his 50th goal in all competitions since joining ''the Reds'' by scoring the opener in a 3–2 home victory over [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], ending Spurs' 12-match unbeaten run. He was also named man of the match for his performance after he won the decisive penalty which [[Steven Gerrard]] converted.
At the end of the season, Suárez was one of six players named on the shortlist for [[PFA Players' Player of the Year]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/gordon-taylor-assesses-the-pfa-player-of-the-year-nominees-8580302.html |title=Gordon Taylor assesses The PFA Player of the Year nominees |date=19 April 2013|accessdate=8 August 2013 |work=The Independent |first=Simon |last=Stone}}</ref> Suárez finished second in the final ballot behind [[Gareth Bale]] of Tottenham<ref name="pfa">{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11669/8679420/luis-suarezs-name-booed-twice-at-pfa-player-of-the-year-awards |title=Luis Suarez's name booed twice at PFA Player of the Year awards |date=29 April 2013 |accessdate=8 August 2013 |work=BSkyB}}</ref> and was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year]].<ref name="pfa"/> He was second-[[2012–13 Premier League#Top scorers|top goalscorer]] in the Premier League for [[2012–13 Premier League|2012–13]] with 23 goals and Liverpool's top scorer in all competitions with 30 goals.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-07-22/liverpool-manager-rodgers-says-he-s-relaxed-about-suarez-future.html |title=Liverpool Manager Rodgers Says He's Relaxed About Suarez Future |date=22 July 2013 |accessdate=8 August 2013|work=Bloomberg}}</ref> On 28 May 2013, he was named as Liverpool's player of the season after receiving 64% of votes in a poll of the club's supporters.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/your-player-of-the-season-revealed |title=Your player of the season revealed |date=28 May 2013 |accessdate=8 August 2013 |work=Liverpool Football Club |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605215636/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/your-player-of-the-season-revealed |archivedate=5 June 2013 |df= }}</ref> [[File:Luis Suarez free kick v Zenit.jpg|thumb|Suárez about to score a 35-yard free kick against [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]], his second goal in a 3–1 win, March 2013]]
=====Second biting incident===== On 21 April 2013, during a 2–2 draw with [[Chelsea F.C|Chelsea]] in a Premier League match at Anfield, Suárez bit [[Branislav Ivanović]]; this was the second time Suárez had bitten an opponent. It was not noticed by the officials, and Suárez scored an equaliser in injury time.<ref name="BranBite"/> The bite prompted [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|UK Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]] to call on the FA to take a hard line with Suárez: the FA charged him with violent conduct and he was fined an undisclosed sum by his club.<ref name="Cameron"/> Contrary to claims from Suárez, Ivanović did not accept an apology.<ref name="Cameron">{{cite news |title=David Cameron calls on FA to take hard line with Luis Suárez over bite |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/apr/22/luis-suarez-charged-biting-ivanovic |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=7 June 2013 |first=Andy |last=Hunter |date=22 April 2013}}</ref> Suárez accepted the violent conduct charge but denied the FA's claim the standard punishment of three matches was clearly insufficient for his offence.<ref>{{cite news |last=Hunter |first=Andy |title=Luis Suárez says three-match ban is enough for biting Branislav Ivanovic |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/apr/23/luis-suarez-liverpool-fa-bite |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=7 June 2013 |date=23 April 2013}}</ref> A three-man independent panel appointed by the FA decided on a ten-game ban for Suárez, who did not appeal the ban; the panel criticised Suárez for not appreciating "the seriousness" of the incident when he argued against a long ban. The panel also wanted to send a "strong message that such deplorable behaviours do not have a place in football", while noting that "all players in the higher level of the game are seen as role models, have the duty to act professionally and responsibly, and set the highest example of good conduct to the rest of the game – especially to young players".<ref>{{cite web |title=Luis Suarez: Panel criticises Liverpool striker's reaction |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22311782 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |accessdate=7 June 2013}}</ref>
On 31 May 2013, Suárez said he would be seeking an exit from Liverpool in the summer, citing excessive media attention on his family as a reason for wanting to leave.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/10091490/Luis-Suarez-I-want-to-leave-Liverpool.html |title=Luis Suarez: I want to leave Liverpool |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |date=31 May 2013 |accessdate=31 August 2014}}</ref> On 6 August, after Liverpool had rejected a bid of [[Pounds sterling|£]]40,000,001 for the player from Arsenal, Suárez reiterated his wish to leave Liverpool and said Liverpool had previously promised to allow him a transfer if the club failed to qualify for the [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/aug/06/luis-suarez-liverpool-arsenal-transfer |title=Luis Suárez: Let me leave, Liverpool – just like you promised |date=6 August 2013 |work=The Guardian}}</ref> The following day, Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers said Liverpool had not broken any promises to Suárez and that the player had shown "total disrespect" for the club.<ref name="alone">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23610289 |title=Luis Suarez: Brendan Rodgers tells Liverpool striker to train alone |date=7 August 2013 |work=BBC Sport}}</ref> After this incident, the British press reported that Suárez had been instructed to train away from the Liverpool first-team squad by Rodgers.<ref name="alone"/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/aug/07/luis-suarez-liverpool-outcast |title=Outcast Luis Suárez is told to train away from Liverpool squad |date=8 August 2013 |work=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1125965/suarez-forced-to-train-alone |title=Suarez Forced To Train Alone |date=8 August 2013 |work=BSkyB}}</ref> On 8 August, Liverpool owner [[John W. Henry]] stated that Suárez would not be allowed to leave the club.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23627573 |title=Luis Suarez: Liverpool owner John W Henry says striker not for sale |date=8 August 2013 |work=BBC Sport}}</ref>
====2013–14 season, Player of the Year==== On 14 August, Suárez appeared to reverse his position about wanting to leave the club, with reports stating he wanted to stay at the club and that he was possibly going to sign a contract extension, citing the support from Liverpool supporters as the reason for his unexpected turnaround.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/transfers/transfer-news-luis-suarez-deals-a-blow-to-arsenal-after-surprise-uturn-in-bid-to-remain-with-liverpool-8760742.html |title=Transfer news: Arsenal hopes reignited after Luis Suarez denies saying he wants to stay at Liverpool |work=The Independent |location=London |date=14 August 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014 |first1=Simon |last1=Rice |first2=Jack |last2=de Menezes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/aug/14/luis-suarez-liverpool |title=Luis Suárez says he will stay at Liverpool |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/10241822/Luis-Suarez-staying-at-Liverpool-with-reports-in-Uruguay-claiming-he-will-sign-new-deal-at-Anfield.html |title=Luis Suarez 'staying' at Liverpool with reports in Uruguay claiming he will sign new deal at Anfield |work=The Daily Telegraph |date= 14 August 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> Suárez returned to first-team training two days later after "offer[ing] contrition" to his teammates but reportedly not apologising to his manager.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/aug/16/luis-suarez-liverpool-apology-training |title=Luis Suárez resumes Liverpool training but offers Rodgers no apology |first=Andy |last=Hunter |work=The Guardian |date=16 August 2013 |accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref>
On 25 September, Suárez returned to the Liverpool team after his suspension to make his first appearance of the [[2013–14 Liverpool F.C. season|2013–14 season]] in a [[2013–14 Football League Cup|League Cup]] third round tie against Manchester United at [[Old Trafford]], losing 1–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/145766-reds-suffer-cup-exit-on-suarez-s-return|title=Reds suffer cup exit on Suarez's return |date=25 September 2013 |accessdate=5 October 2013|work=Liverpool FC}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24140621 |title=Manchester United 1 0 Liverpool |accessdate=5 October 2013|date=25 September 2013 |work=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 29 September, Suárez made his first [[2013–14 Premier League|Premier League]] appearance of the season, scoring twice as Liverpool defeated [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 3–1 at the [[Stadium of Light]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/146001-suarez-and-sturridge-down-sunderland |title=Suarez and Sturridge down Sunderland |date=29 September 2013 |accessdate=5 October 2013|work=Liverpool FC}}</ref> On 5 October, Suárez made his first appearance of the season at Anfield, where he scored Liverpool's opening goal in a 3–1 win against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/oct/05/liverpool-crystal-palace-premier-league |title=Liverpool's Luis Suárez and Daniel Sturridge put Crystal Palace to sword |date=6 October 2013 |work=The Guardian}}</ref> On 26 October, he scored his fourth Premier League hat-trick, his first at Anfield, in a 4–1 defeat of [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]. According to the [[BBC]], he has [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|scored a hat-trick]] every 20.3 Premier League matches, "the best rate of all 46 players to have scored more than one treble" in the top tier.<ref name="BBC">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24591245 |title=Liverpool – West Brom |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=26 October 2013}}</ref>
{{Quote box|width=27%|align=right|quote="He [Suárez] has shown in his time at Liverpool in the last year or so that he is near unplayable. He on his own can occupy a back four with his movement and his cleverness."|source=— [[Brendan Rodgers]], Liverpool manager, in a season when Suárez was player of the year.<ref>[http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/273287.html "Suarez near unplayable – Rodgers"]. ESPN. Retrieved 20 May 2014</ref>}}
On 4 December, Suárez scored four goals against Norwich City in a 5–1 home win.<ref>{{cite web|title=Suarez hits four in Liverpool win|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25115744|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=4 December 2013|date=4 December 2013}}</ref> He became the first player in Premier League history to score three hat-tricks against the same club, and took his scoring record against Norwich to 11 goals in 5 matches.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/301797/report|title=Premier League: Luis Suarez scores four goals as Liverpool beat Norwich 5–1 |date=4 December 2013 |work=BSkyB}}</ref> On 15 December, Suárez captained Liverpool for the first time in a Premier League match against Tottenham Hotspur.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.fifa.com/world-match-centre/news/newsid/224/674/6/index.html|title=Suarez: The team is the captain |date=16 December 2013 |work=FIFA}}</ref> He scored twice and assisted once as the team recorded a 5–0 win at [[White Hart Lane]] to close the gap on league leaders Arsenal to two points.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25287554|title=Tottenham 0 5 Liverpool |date=15 December 2013 |work=BBC Sport}}</ref> The following day, Suárez was named the [[Football Supporters' Federation|Football Supporters' Federation Player of the Year]] for 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=WINNERS: FSF Awards in association with William Hill|url=http://fsf.org.uk/latest-news/view/WINNERS-FSF-Awards-in-association-with-William-Hill|publisher=FSF.org.uk |accessdate=18 July 2015|date=17 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/players/luis-suarez/10521865/Liverpools-Luis-Suarez-a-humble-winner-of-FSF-Player-of-the-Year-award.html |title=Liverpool's Luis Suarez a humble winner of FSF Player of the Year award |date=16 December 2013 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |first=Henry |last=Winter}}</ref> On 20 December, Suárez signed a new four-and-a-half-year contract with Liverpool.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/151639-luis-suarez-signs-new-contract-at-lfc |title=Luis Suarez signs new contract at LFC |date=20 December 2013 |accessdate=20 December 2013 |publisher=Liverpool F.C.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Luis Suarez signs new long-term Liverpool deal |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25463249 |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=20 December 2013 |date=20 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/dec/20/luis-suarez-signs-long-term-liverpool-deal |title=Luis Suárez signs long-term deal to stay at Liverpool until 2018 |date=20 December 2013 |accessdate=26 December 2013 |work=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref>
On 1 January 2014, by scoring in a 2–0 home win over [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]], Suárez became the first Liverpool player to score 20 or more goals in successive Premier League seasons since Robbie Fowler in [[1994–95 Liverpool F.C. season|1994–95]] and [[1995–96 Liverpool F.C. season|1995–96]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25513270 |title=Liverpool 2 0 Hull |date=1 January 2014 |work=BBC Sport}}</ref> He equalled [[Andy Cole]]'s Premier League record for the earliest date to reach the 20-goal mark, but set a new record low of 15 matches.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/liverpool-2-hull-city-0-luis-suarez-hits-recordequalling-goal-to-help-brendan-rodgers-reds-past-the-tigers-9032801.html |title=Liverpool 2 Hull City 0: Luis Suarez hits record-equalling goal to help Brendan Rodgers' Reds past the Tigers |work=Evening Standard |location=London |date=1 January 2013 |accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref> His strike partnership this season with [[Daniel Sturridge]] has earned them a nickname "SAS", ''i.e.'', ''Sturridge and Suárez".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Watson|first1=Jack|title="I'm One of the Best Players in the World" – Liverpool's £22m Superstar States|url=http://www.squawka.com/news/im-one-of-the-best-players-in-the-world-liverpools-22m-superstar-argues/79534|accessdate=1 July 2017|work=Squawka Football News|date=7 March 2014|language=en}}</ref>
On 1 March, Suárez made his 100th Premier League appearance, scoring in a 3–0 win over [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] at [[St Mary's Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/southampton-0-liverpool-3-match-report-luis-suarez-and-raheem-sterling-on-target-as-liverpool-soar-into-title-reckoning-9162524.html |title=Southampton 0 Liverpool 3 match report: Luis Suarez and Raheem Sterling on target as Liverpool soar into title reckoning |date=2 March 2013 |accessdate=24 March 2014 |work=The Independent |location=London |first=Nick |last=Szczepanik}}</ref> In the following fixture, he scored his 25th league goal of the season as Liverpool defeated Manchester United at Old Trafford for the first time since 2009 by a convincing three-goal margin.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-united/10701050/Manchester-United-0-Liverpool-3-match-report.html |title=Manchester United 0 Liverpool 3: match report |date=16 March 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2014 |work=The Telegraph |location=London |first=Henry |last=Winter}}</ref> On 22 March, Suárez scored his sixth [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|Premier League hat-trick]], and third of the season, in a 6–3 win over [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] at the [[Cardiff City Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/293689.html|title=Suarez hat-trick continues title assault|date=22 March 2014|work=ESPN}}</ref> On 30 March, he broke Robbie Fowler's club record of 28 goals in a Premier League season in a 4–0 home win against Tottenham which took Liverpool top of the league with six matches remaining.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/295819.html |title=Suarez into the record books as Liverpool go top |date=30 March 2014 |work=ESPN}}</ref> On 20 April, he scored in a 3–2 win at Norwich to become the first Liverpool player to score 30 league goals in a season since [[Ian Rush]] in [[1986–87 Liverpool F.C. season|1986–87]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-fc-striker-luis-suarez-7011238 |title=Liverpool FC striker Luis Suarez becomes first Reds player since Rush to score 30 league goals in a season |date=20 April 2014 |accessdate=20 April 2014 |work=Liverpool Echo}}</ref> This also made him the seventh player to score 30 goals in a Premier League season, following Andy Cole, [[Alan Shearer]], [[Kevin Phillips (footballer)|Kevin Phillips]], [[Thierry Henry]], [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] and [[Robin van Persie]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/will-luis-suarez-break-the-premier-league-goal-scoring-record-this-season-29861426.html |title=Will Luis Suarez break the Premier League goal scoring record this season? |date=23 December 2013 |accessdate=20 April 2014 |work=The Independent (Ireland)}}</ref>
On 18 April, Suárez was named as one of the six players nominated for the [[PFA Player of the Year]] award for the second consecutive season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27076251 |title=PFA award: Liverpool's Suarez, Gerrard & Sturridge on shortlist |date=18 April 2014 |accessdate=19 April 2014 |work=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 27 April, he won the award, becoming the first non-European to win the award.<ref name="Guardian">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/apr/28/luis-suarez-liverpool-pfa-player-of-year-award |title=Luis Suárez of Liverpool wins PFA player of the year award |date=28 April 2014 |work=Guardian |accessdate=29 April 2014 }}</ref> On 5 May 2014, Suárez was named as the [[FWA Footballer of the Year|Football Association Writers]] Player of the Year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/305239.html |title= Suarez wins football writers' award |date=5 May 2014 |work=ESPN |accessdate=7 May 2014}}</ref> He finished the season with 31 goals in 33 matches, winning the [[Premier League Golden Boot]], with Sturridge as runner-up,<ref>{{cite web |title=English Premier League Stats: Top Goal Scorers – 2013–14 |url=http://www.espnfc.com/stats/scorers/_/league/eng.1/barclays-premier-league |publisher=[[ESPN]] |accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref> as Liverpool came second in the league and returned to the UEFA Champions League. Suárez also won the Barclay's [[Premier League Player of the Season]] award.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27389970|title=Luis Suarez & Tony Pulis win Barclays Premier League awards |date=13 May 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref> As the Premier League's top scorer with 31 goals, he also shared the [[European Golden Shoe]] with Cristiano Ronaldo. On 21 May 2014, Suárez ranked number one on "Europe's most influential player" list of the year, ahead of [[Lionel Messi]], [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]] and Cristiano Ronaldo, according to a study by [[50 Most Influential (Bloomberg Markets ranking)|Bloomberg]] of the [[European Professional Football Leagues|top five European leagues]].<ref name="BSports Power 50">{{cite news|url=https://www.bsports.com/statsinsights/football/suarez-tops-bsports-power-50-messi-ibrahimovic-ronaldo |title=Suarez tops the BSports Power 50 ahead of Messi, Ibrahimovic & Ronaldo |date=21 May 2014 |accessdate=21 May 2014 |publisher=bsports.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521201910/https://www.bsports.com/statsinsights/football/suarez-tops-bsports-power-50-messi-ibrahimovic-ronaldo |archivedate=21 May 2014 |df= }}</ref>
===Barcelona=== ====Signing and suspension==== [[File:Luis Suarez FCB 2014.jpg|thumb|200px|Suárez making his Barcelona debut against [[Club León]] in August 2014. After serving his four month suspension for biting at the 2014 World Cup he made his competitive debut for the club on 25 October.]] On 11 July 2014, Suárez agreed with [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] on a five-year contract for an undisclosed transfer fee.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/fc-barcelona-and-liverpool-fc-have-reached-an-agreement-for-the-transfer-of-luis-suarez|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712034551/http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/fc-barcelona-and-liverpool-fc-have-reached-an-agreement-for-the-transfer-of-luis-suarez|title=FC Barcelona and Liverpool FC have reached an agreement for the transfer of Luis Suárez|date=11 July 2014|access-date=15 July 2017|archivedate=12 July 2014|publisher=F.C. Barcelona}}</ref> However, according to a leaked document by [[Football Leaks]], the fee was £64.98 million (€82.3 million), making him [[List of most expensive association football transfers|one of the most expensive players]] in world football history.<ref name="Revealed: How much Luis Suarez really cost Barcelona">{{cite news|title=Revealed: How much Luis Suarez really cost Barcelona|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/03/28/revealed-how-much-luis-suarez-really-cost-barcelona/|date=28 March 2016|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|access-date=24 August 2016|language=English}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/luis-suarezs-barcelona-transfer-fee-7641002 |title=Luis Suarez's Barcelona transfer fee "revealed as £65m" – £10m LESS than his Liverpool release clause|date=28 March 2016|work=Mirror|accessdate=29 August 2016|author=Whaling, James}}</ref> ''Barça'' confirmed Suárez would wear the number 9 shirt for the [[2014–15 FC Barcelona season|2014–15 season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/luis-suarez-el-9-del-barca|title=Luis Suárez, FC Barcelona's number 9|date=11 July 2014|publisher=[[FC Barcelona]]|accessdate=12 July 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712034428/http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/luis-suarez-el-9-del-barca|archivedate=12 July 2014}}</ref>
Suárez missed the first part of the season after being found guilty of biting Italian player [[Giorgio Chiellini]] at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref name="FIFABan">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2014/m=6/news=luis-suarez-suspended-for-nine-matches-and-banned-for-four-months-from-2386354.html |title=Luis Suárez suspended for nine matches and banned for four months from any football-related activity |publisher=[[FIFA]] |date=26 June 2014 |accessdate=30 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140703172739/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y%3D2014/m%3D6/news%3Dluis-suarez-suspended-for-nine-matches-and-banned-for-four-months-from-2386354.html |archivedate= 3 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="Ban2014">{{cite news |last=De Menezes |first=Jack |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/worldcup/luis-suarez-banned-fifa-hand-striker-record-ninegame-ban-and-a-four-month-football-ban-for-biting-giorgio-chiellini-in-biggest-ever-world-cup-suspension-9565686.html |title=Luis Suarez banned: Fifa hand striker record nine-game ban AND a four month football ban for biting Giorgio Chiellini in biggest ever World Cup suspension |date=26 June 2014 |accessdate=26 June 2014 |publisher=The Independent}}</ref> As part of the suspension, he was banned from all "football-related activities", including training for Barcelona, for four months (until 26 October). He was also banned from entering any stadium, even as a spectator, during the same period.<ref name="FIFABan"/><ref name="Ban2014"/>
On 24 July, Suárez and his lawyers filed an appeal with the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] (CAS) and requested the sanctions be reduced or the suspension to be lifted.<ref name="cas">{{cite news|publisher=[[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] |title=FOOTBALL – Decision in the Luis Suarez case |url=http://www.tas-cas.org/d2wfiles/document/4201/5048/0/Media20Release20366520(English)201420082014.pdf |accessdate=14 August 2014 |date=14 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821081809/http://www.tas-cas.org/d2wfiles/document/4201/5048/0/Media20Release20366520%28English%29201420082014.pdf |archivedate=21 August 2014 |df= }}</ref> The parties were heard at a hearing which took place at the CAS offices in [[Lausanne]], Switzerland, on 8 August.<ref name="cas2">{{cite news|publisher=[[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] |title=CAS hears the appeal of Luis Suarez |url=http://www.tas-cas.org/d2wfiles/document/4201/5048/0/Media20Release20366520(English)201420082014.pdf |accessdate=8 August 2014 |date=8 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821081809/http://www.tas-cas.org/d2wfiles/document/4201/5048/0/Media20Release20366520%28English%29201420082014.pdf |archivedate=21 August 2014 |df= }}</ref> Six days later, the CAS confirmed the ban imposed by [[FIFA]] against Suárez, who remained suspended from football for four months, as well as a nine-match ban in internationals, the first of which was served in the [[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Colombia vs Uruguay|Uruguay's round of 16 match against Colombia]] in the 2014 World Cup. However, the CAS removed the player's "football-related activities" ban and was allowed to train with Barcelona. As a result of this ban, Suárez was banned from participating in the [[2015 Copa América]].
The CAS permitted Suárez to play in friendly matches, and he made his Barcelona debut on 18 August against [[Club León]] of Mexico at the [[Camp Nou]], replacing [[Rafinha (footballer, born February 1993)|Rafinha]] for the final 14 minutes of an eventual 6–0 win in the [[Gamper Trophy]]. Fellow forwards Lionel Messi and [[Neymar]] had already been substituted off by the time Suárez took to the pitch.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lowe|first1=Sid|title=Luis Suárez finally makes Barcelona bow as substitute against León|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/aug/18/luis-suarez-barcelona-debut|accessdate=23 August 2014|work=The Guardian|date=18 August 2014}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== Suárez made his competitive debut for Barcelona on 25 October, starting in attack with Lionel Messi and Neymar away to [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] in ''[[El Clásico]]''.<ref name="Clasico"/> Although he set up Neymar for the opening goal in the fourth minute, Suárez was substituted in the second half and Barcelona lost 3–1.<ref name="Clasico">{{cite news|last1=Sanghera|first1=Mandeep|title=Real Madrid 3–1 Barcelona|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29541443|accessdate=25 October 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=25 October 2014}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club on 26 November in a 4–0 win at [[APOEL FC|APOEL]] in the [[2014–15 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] [[2014–15 UEFA Champions League group stage|group stage]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Papantonopoulou|first1=Vassiliki|title=Record-breaker Messi leads Barça stroll at APOEL|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2015/matches/round=2000548/match=2014381/postmatch/report/index.html#messi+shoots+down+apoel|accessdate=26 November 2014|publisher=UEFA|date=25 November 2014}}</ref> On 20 December, he scored his first league goal for the club in his eighth [[La Liga]] match, contributing to a 5–0 home win against [[Córdoba CF|Córdoba]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Barcelona 5–0 Córdoba|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30483708|accessdate=21 December 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=20 December 2014}}</ref>
On 24 February 2015, Suárez scored twice as ''Barça'' defeated English champions [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] 2–1 in the first leg of their UEFA Champions League [[2014–15 UEFA Champions League knockout stage#Round of 16|round of 16]] tie.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/feb/24/manchester-city-barcelona-champions-league-match-report|title=Manchester City 1–2 Barcelona|date=25 February 2015|work=The Guardian}}</ref> On 4 March, he scored in Barcelona's 3–1 [[2014–15 Copa del Rey|Copa del Rey]] semi-final win over [[Villarreal CF|Villarreal]] to qualify the club for its 37th [[Copa del Rey|Spanish Cup]] [[2015 Copa del Rey Final|final]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/31721178|title=Villarreal 1–3 Barcelona|date=4 March 2015|work=BBC}}</ref> On 8 March, Suárez scored twice in a 6–1 home win over [[Rayo Vallecano]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2985005/Barcelona-6-1-Rayo-Vallecano-Lionel-Messi-second-half-hat-trick-Luis-Suarez-double-fuel-win-Barca-La-Liga.html|title=Barcelona 6–1 Rayo Vallecano: Lionel Messi 12-minute hat-trick (his fastest ever) and Luis Suarez double fuel win to move Barca top of La Liga... as both teams have a man sent off in hectic.|date=8 March 2015|work=Daily Mail}}</ref> On 22 March 2015, Suárez scored the winning goal for Barcelona in the 2–1 victory over Real Madrid at [[Camp Nou]].<ref name="El Clasico">{{cite news|title=Barcelona 2–1 Real Madrid: Luis Suarez 'scores like few others|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32013192|agency=BBC|issue=22 March 2015|date=23 March 2015}}</ref> In the post-match press conference, his coach [[Luis Enrique (footballer)|Luis Enrique]] lauded Suárez, saying, "Very few players can score a goal like he did, and that is why we signed him. He can decide games. He's a pure scorer, who needs very little to finish."<ref name="El Clasico"/>
On 15 April, Suárez scored two goals in a 3–1 UEFA Champions League quarter-final first leg victory over [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] at the [[Parc des Princes]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32295986|title=Paris St G 1–3 Barcelona|date=15 April 2015|work=BBC}}</ref> He [[Nutmeg (football)|nutmegged]] PSG defender [[David Luiz]] twice before scoring both goals.<ref>{{cite news|title=WATCH: Luis Suarez nutmeg David Luiz twice in Barcelona's win at PSG |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11945/9807385/watch-luis-suarez-nutmegs-david-luiz-twice-in-barcelonas-win-at-psg |agency=Sky Sports |date=16 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150527190240/http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11945/9807385/watch-luis-suarez-nutmegs-david-luiz-twice-in-barcelonas-win-at-psg |archivedate=27 May 2015 |df= }}</ref> On 2 May, he scored his first hat-trick for the club, in 8–0 win at Córdoba.<ref>{{cite web|title=Córdoba 0–8 Barcelona|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32553122|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 May 2015}}</ref> Suárez scored in the [[2015 UEFA Champions League Final|Champions League final]] against [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] on 6 June in [[Berlin]], putting the team back into the lead in an eventual 3–1 win by converting the rebound after [[Gianluigi Buffon]] saved from Messi. The win sealed a [[Treble (association football)|treble]] for the team.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Haslam|first1=Andrew|title=Barcelona see off Juventus to claim fifth title|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2015/matches/round=2000552/match=2015227/postmatch/report/index.html#barcelona+juventus+claim+fifth+title|accessdate=6 June 2015|publisher=UEFA|date=6 June 2015}}</ref>
Suárez ended his first season at Barcelona with 25 goals and 20 assists in all competitions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/people/uruguay/16639/luis-su%C3%A1rez|title=Luis Suárez|access-date=7 June 2015|work=Goal.com}}</ref> The Barcelona attacking trio of Messi, Suárez and Neymar, dubbed "MSN", ended with 122 goals, the most in a season for an attacking trio in Spanish football history.<ref name="MSN record">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jun/06/barcelona-luis-suarez-lionel-messi-juventus-champions-league-final|title=Barcelona's Luis Suárez, Leo Messi and Neymar too good for Juventus|date=6 June 2015|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== [[File:2015 UEFA Super Cup 79.jpg|thumb|Suárez strikes against [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] in the [[2015 UEFA Super Cup]].]] Suárez opened the season by scoring and assisting on a goal in Barcelona's 5–4 extra-time victory over [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] in the [[2015 UEFA Super Cup]], on 11 August 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=Barcelona 5–4 Sevilla|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33872239|accessdate=12 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 August 2015}}</ref> The next day, he was named one of the three finalists for the [[UEFA Best Player in Europe Award#2014–15|2015 UEFA Best Player in Europe Award]].<ref name="Best Player in Europe"/> On 31 October, Suárez scored in a 2–0 away win against [[Getafe CF|Getafe]] after being assisted with a backheel from [[Sergi Roberto]].<ref name="300 goals"/> This was his 11th goal of the season and his 300th senior career goal.<ref name="300 goals"/> On 21 November, Suárez scored twice in Barcelona's 4–0 away win against Real Madrid.<ref>{{cite news|title=Suarez scores twice as Barca thrash Real|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34849342|agency=BBC|accessdate=21 November 2015}}</ref>
On 17 December, Suárez scored all three goals as Barcelona defeated Chinese club [[Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao F.C.|Guangzhou Evergrande]] 3–0 in the [[2015 FIFA Club World Cup]] semi-final in [[Yokohama]], Japan, becoming the first player to score a hat-trick in [[FIFA Club World Cup|the competition]]'s history.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/luis-suarez-scores-first-ever-hat-trick-in-club-world-cup|title=Luis Suárez scores first ever hat-trick in Club World Cup|date=17 December 2015|work=Futbol Club Barcelona}}</ref> He then scored twice in Barcelona's 3–0 win over Argentine club [[Club Atlético River Plate|River Plate]] in [[2015 FIFA Club World Cup Final|the final]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Begley|first1=Emlyn|title=River Plate 0–3 Barcelona|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/35141742|accessdate=20 December 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=20 December 2015}}</ref> Suárez finished the tournament as top scorer with five goals and was also named the best player of the tournament.<ref name="CWC awards">{{cite web|title=Barcelona trio sweep awards|url=https://www.fifa.com/clubworldcup/news/y=2015/m=12/news=barcelona-trio-raumt-ab-2747108-2747184.html|website=FIFA.com|accessdate=20 December 2015|language=en-GB|date=20 December 2015}}</ref>
On 3 February 2016, Suárez scored four goals in the 7–0 [[2015–16 Copa del Rey|Copa del Rey]] win against [[Valencia CF|Valencia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=El Barça enciende la consola|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2015_16/copa/semifinal/ida/bar_val/|website=Marca.com|accessdate=3 February 2016|language=en-GB|date=3 February 2016}}</ref> On 20 April, he again scored four times in a match, as well as assisting three further goals for teammates, as ''Barça'' won 8–0 away at [[Deportivo de La Coruña]] in La Liga. Only three days later, he scored another four goals in a 6–0 home win over [[Sporting de Gijón]], for which Suárez became the first player to score four times in two consecutive matches in the history of La Liga.<ref>{{cite news|title=Barcelona 6–0 Sporting Gijon: Luis Suarez nets four as MSN all score to help Barcelona shrug off pressure from the chasing pack and return to the top of La Liga|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3555534/Barcelona-6-0-Sporting-Gijon-Luis-Suarez-nets-four-MSN-score-help-Barcelona-shrug-pressure-chasing-pack-return-La-Liga.html|accessdate=23 April 2016|work=Daily Mail|date=23 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Luis Suárez arrebata a Cristiano Ronaldo el Pichich|url=http://www.marca.com/futbol/barcelona/2016/04/23/571bd59446163fb72c8b45a2.html|date=23 April 2016|accessdate=23 April 2016|work=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=spanish}}</ref> On 30 April, Suárez became the second player in the history of the club to reach the milestone of 35 goals in a single season.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/88/spain/2016/04/30/22983522/35-and-counting-suarez-joins-messi-in-elite-club-of-la-ligas|title=35 and counting: Suarez joins Messi in elite club of La Liga's highest scorer|date=30 April 2016|publisher=goal.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3579673/Barcelona-5-0-Espanyol-Luis-Suarez-Lionel-Messi-Neymar-score-Barca-thrash-rivals-leave-brink-La-Liga-title.html|title=Barcelona 5–0 Espanyol: Luis Suarez, Lionel Messi and Neymar all score as Barca thrash rivals to leave them on brink of La Liga title|date=8 May 2016|work=[[Daily Mail]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/la-liga-title-race-barcelona-7925678|title=La Liga title race: Barcelona still lead after dramatic penultimate day|date=8 May 2016|work=[[Daily Mirror]]}}</ref>
On the final day of the [[2015–16 La Liga]] season, Suárez scored a hat-trick in a 3–0 victory at [[Granada CF|Granada]] to win the [[List of Spanish football champions|Spanish championship]] for ''Barça'' and registered 40 league goals for the season to win the [[Pichichi Trophy]], for which Suárez became the first player since 2009 to win both the Pichichi and the [[European Golden Shoe]] other than Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbssports.com/soccer/news/ronaldo-subbed-off-by-real-madrid-waving-white-flag-on-la-liga-pichichi-races/|title=Final Pichichi and Golden Shoe standings: Barcelona's Luis Suarez the winner|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=16 May 2016|publisher=[[CBS]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36250300|title=Granada CF 0–3 Barcelona|date=14 May 2016|work=BBC}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36293793|title=Luis Suarez: Barcelona striker hits hat-trick to win Pichichi – La Liga's golden boot|date=14 May 2016|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref> Fourteen of his goals came in his last five matches. Suárez also led the league in assists, tied at 16 with Messi, becoming the first player ever to lead La Liga in both goals and assists.<ref name="Goal.com"/><ref name="Luis Suarez Player Profile"/>
On 22 May 2016, Suárez suffered a season-ending injury during Barcelona's 2–0 victory over Sevilla in the [[2016 Copa del Rey Final]]. The club confirmed after the match that Suárez had suffered an injury to his [[Pulled hamstring|right hamstring]], and would likely miss at least part of the upcoming [[Copa América Centenario]] with [[Uruguay national football team|his national football team]]. For Uruguay, Suárez also previously missed part of the 2014 World Cup and the entire 2015 Copa América through suspension.<ref name="Suárez set to miss start of Copa América">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/23/copa-america-uruguay-barcelona-luis-suarez-injury|title=Uruguay's Luis Suárez set to miss start of Copa América with hamstring injury|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=23 May 2016|accessdate=23 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="hamstring injury">{{Cite news|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/fc-barcelona-s-luis-suarez-diagnosed-with-right-hamstring-injury|title=Luis Suárez diagnosed with right hamstring injury|publisher=fcbarcelona.com|date=23 May 2016|accessdate=23 May 2016}}</ref> The front three of Messi, Suárez and Neymar finished the season with 131 goals, breaking the record they had set the previous year for most goals by an attacking trio in a single season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Messi, Suárez and Neymar Jr end season with 131 goals |url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2015-2016/messi-suarez-and-neymar-jr-end-season-with-131-goals |accessdate=5 August 2018 |agency=FC Barcelona}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== Suárez opened his goal scoring account by scoring a goal in the first leg of the [[2016 Supercopa de España]] against Sevilla and winning the match 0–2. In the first match of the [[2016–17 La Liga]] season, Suárez scored a hat-trick in a 6–2 victory against [[Real Betis]] in which he scored his first free-kick goal for Barcelona.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2016-2017/luis-suarez-joins-fc-barcelona-s-free-kick-club|title=Luis Suárez joins FC Barcelona's free-kick club {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=www.fcbarcelona.com|access-date=24 August 2016}}</ref> Suárez made his 100th Barcelona appearance in a 2–1 defeat at home to [[Deportivo Alavés|Alavés]]. Though unable to score, Suárez claimed the distinction of scoring more goals and assists in his first 100 matches in Spain than both Cristiano Ronaldo and Messi; Suárez contributed 88 goals and 43 assists in his first 100 matches for Barcelona, compared to Ronaldo's 95 goals and 29 assists, and Messi's 41 goals and 14 assists.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wright|first1=Nick|title=Luis Suarez at 100 games: Barcelona star beats Cristiano Ronaldo's record|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11096/10574246/luis-suarez-at-100-games-barcelona-star-beats-cristiano-ronaldos-record|website=Sky Sports News|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref>
Suárez opened his [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] account for the season with two goals in a 7–0 defeat of [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]; this was followed by another goal in a 5–1 defeat of [[CD Leganés|Leganés]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hill|first1=Tim|title=Barcelona 7–0 Celtic|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2016/sep/13/barcelona-celtic-champions-league-live|website=The Guardian|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Leganes 1–5 Barcelona|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37388264|website=BBC Sport|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> On 11 January 2017, Suárez scored his 100th goal for Barcelona in a [[2016–17 Copa del Rey|Copa del Rey]] round of 16 match against [[Athletic Bilbao]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://it.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=2435197.html|title=Barcellona: Suárez nel club dei 100|date=11 January 2017|work=UEFA|language=Italian}}</ref>
On 7 February, Suárez scored and was later sent off for a second yellow in the semi-final match of the Copa del Rey against [[Atlético Madrid]] for an alleged foul on [[Koke (footballer, born 1992)|Koke]], his first red card competitively for Barcelona, meaning he would miss the [[2017 Copa del Rey Final|final]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dobson|first1=Mark|title=Luis Suárez sent off as nine-man Barcelona edge out Atlético Madrid|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/feb/07/luis-suarez-barcelona-sent-off-atletico-madrid-camp-nou-copa-del-rey|website=The Guardian|accessdate=7 February 2017}}</ref> In an interview after the match, Suárez said he strongly disagreed with the decision, and wished to appeal it, saying, "I'm laughing at that second yellow, it's not even a foul. I did absolutely nothing. I hope the club will appeal it."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Marsden|first1=Samuel|title=Luis Suarez hopes Barcelona appeal his red card, says 'It's not even a foul' |url=http://www.espnfc.com/barcelona/story/3056061/luis-suarez-hopes-barcelona-appeal-his-red-card-its-not-even-a-foul|website=ESPN FC|accessdate=7 February 2017}}</ref>
====2017–18 season====
On 23 September, Suárez scored in Barcelona’s win over [[Girona Futbol Club|Girona]] in the first ever Catalan derby for the opposition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/match-report-girona-fc-0-3-fc-barcelona-top-cats|title=Girona FC 0–3 FC Barcelona: Top cats {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-23}}</ref> On 14 October, Suárez maintained Barcelona’s undefeated start to a La Liga season with a late header against [[Atlético Madrid]] at the [[Wanda Metropolitano]] in Madrid.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/match-report-atletico-madrid-1-1-fc-barcelona-still-undefeated|title=[MATCH REPORT] Atlético Madrid 1–1 FC Barcelona: Still undefeated {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-14}}</ref> He scored twice against [[CD Leganés|Leganés]] in a 3–0 win at the [[Estadio Municipal de Butarque]] on 18 November.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/match-report-leganes-0-2-fcbarcelona-super-suarez-strikes-twice|title=MATCH REPORT: Leganés 0–3 Barça: Super Suárez strikes twice {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-19}}</ref> On 17 December, Suárez scored two against Deportivo La Coruña in a 4–0 win.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/match-report-fc-barcelona-4-0-deportivo-winter-wonderland|title=FC Barcelona 4–0 Deportivo: Winter wonderland {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref> Less than a week later, Suárez opened the scoring for Barcelona in a 3–0 win over Real Madrid at the Bernabéu.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/real-madrid-0-fcbarcelona-3-messi-christmas-match-report|title=Real Madrid 0 Barça 3: Messi Christmas! {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-23}}</ref>
After the mid season break, on 14 January Suárez scored twice in a 4–2 comeback win at [[Real Sociedad]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/match-report-real-sociedad-v-fc-barcelona-thrilling-comeback-win-4-2-suarez|title=MATCH REPORT: Real Sociedad v FC Barcelona: Thrilling comeback win (2–4) {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> Suarez scored a hat-trick in a 6–1 win over Girona at the Camp Nou on 24 February.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/match-report-barca-girona-unstoppable-6-1-|title=FC Barcelona – Girona: Unstoppable! (6–1) {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> On 31 March, late goals from Suarez and Messi secured a 2–2 draw against Seville at the Ramón Sánchez Pizjuán.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/match-report-sevilla-fc-fc-barcelona-a-minute-of-magic-2-2-|title=Sevilla FC – FC Barcelona: A minute of magic (2–2) {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-31}}</ref> On 14 April, Suárez scored as Barcelona defeated València 2–1 to secure the [[Football records in Spain#Games without a loss|longest unbeaten streak]] (39 games) in La Liga history.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/match-report-fc-barcelona-2-1-valencia-cf-record-breakers|title=FC Barcelona 2–1 València CF: Record breakers {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-14}}</ref>
On 21 April, Barcelona won their fourth consecutive [[Copa del Rey]] title in [[2018 Copa del Rey Final|beating Sevilla 5–0]] in Madrid, with Suárez scoring twice.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/copa-del-rey-final-match-report-sevilla-0-5-fc-barcelona-wanda-ful-|title=Sevilla 0–5 FC Barcelona: Wanda-ful! {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-21}}</ref> Barcelona held on for a dramatic 2–2 draw against Real Madrid on 6 May to extend their unbeaten streak in the league, with Suárez and Messi scoring the goals for Barca, before Cristiano Ronaldo and [[Gareth Bale]] drew Real level.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/match-report-fc-barcelona-vs-real-madrid-still-undefeated-2-2-|title=MATCH REPORT: Barça and Real Madrid draw 2–2, as Catalans extend unbeaten streak {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-06}}</ref> [[Football records in Spain#Games without a loss|Barcelona's record unbeaten streak (43 games)]] came to an end on 13 May losing to Levante 4–5. Barcelona mounted a comeback after trailing 1–5, with Suárez scoring one and new club record signing [[Philippe Coutinho]] scoring a hat-trick.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/match-report-levante-ud-v-fc-barcelona-undefeated-run-comes-to-end-5-4-|title=Levante UD v FC Barcelona: Undefeated run comes to end (5–4) {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref>
====2018–19 season==== On 2 September 2018, Suárez scored twice for Barcelona in an 8–2 win over newly promoted [[SD Huesca|Huesca]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2018-2019/match-report-fc-barcelona-huesca-gr-eight-8-2 |title=FC Barcelona – SD Huesca: Gr-eight! (8–2) |date=2 September 2018 |publisher=FC Barcelona |access-date=2 September 2018}}</ref> A week later he scored in their 2–1 victory at [[Real Sociedad]], as the club made it four wins out of four in La Liga.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2018-2019/match-report-real-societat-1-2-barca-real-delight |title=Real Sociedad 1–2 Barça: Real delight |date=15 September 2018 |publisher=FC Barcelona |access-date=15 September 2018}}</ref> On 28 October, Suárez scored a hat-trick in a 5–1 home win over Real Madrid in ''[[El Clásico]]''.<ref>{{cite news |title=Suarez scores hat-trick as Barca thrash Real in El Clasico |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45995215 |accessdate=28 October 2018 |agency=BBC}}</ref> Suárez is the only the second Barcelona player (after Messi) to score a hat-trick in ''El Clasico'' in La Liga since [[Romário]] in 1994.<ref>{{cite news |title=Excluding Lionel Messi, Luis Suarez is the first @FCBarcelona player to score a hat-trick in #ElClasico in La Liga since Romário in 1994. Exhibition.|url=https://twitter.com/optajose/status/1056593371316346880?s=21 |accessdate=28 October 2018 |agency=OptaJose}}</ref>
==International career== Suárez was invited to play for [[Uruguay national under-20 football team|Uruguay]] in the qualifying rounds for the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2007 U-20 World Cup]], but his club, Groningen, did not release him to play.<ref name="9 Suarez profile"/> He did play in the tournament finals, and he scored two goals in four appearances.<ref name="FIFA stats">{{cite web |url= https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/statisticsandrecords/players/player=270775/index.html |work=FIFA.com |title= Luis SUAREZ |accessdate=21 August 2011}}</ref> His goals came in a group stage draw against [[Spain national under-20 football team|Spain]]<ref name="Bell">{{cite news |url= http://goal.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/07/09/u-20s-usa-vs-uruguay-the-preview/ |title= U-20s: USA vs. Uruguay – the Preview |first= Jack |last=Bell |work=NYTimes.com |publisher= The New York Times Company |date= 9 July 2007 |accessdate=27 August 2011}}</ref> and in the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup#Round of 16|Round of 16]] against the [[United States national under-20 football team|United States]],<ref name="FIFA stats"/> but the U.S. won 2–1 and Uruguay was eliminated from the tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u20worldcup/canada2007/results/match=58881/report.html |title=Match 38 – USA – Uruguay |work=FIFA.com |date=11 July 2007 |accessdate=27 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727235251/http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u20worldcup/canada2007/results/match%3D58881/report.html |archivedate=27 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Suárez made his senior debut for [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] on 8 February 2007 in a 3–1 win against [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]]. He was [[Misconduct (association football)|sent off]] in the 85th minute after receiving a second yellow card for dissent.<ref name="Pearce 1-3"/><ref name="9 Suarez profile"/> Suárez played in 19 of 20 games in [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|2010 World Cup qualifying]] and the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (inter-confederation play-offs)#CONCACAF v CONMEBOL|inter-confederation playoffs]] and scored five goals.<ref name="FIFA stats"/>
===2010 FIFA World Cup=== [[File:Suárez Forlan.jpg|thumb|upright|Suárez (left) and [[Diego Forlán]] at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] in South Africa]] In June 2010, [[Óscar Tabárez]] named Suárez to Uruguay's 23-man [[2010 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] squad.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/news/newsid=1222732/ |title=Tabarez trims Uruguay team to 23 |work=FIFA.com |date=1 June 2010 |agency=Press Association |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140316003930/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/news/newsid%3D1222732/ |archivedate=16 March 2014 |df= }}</ref> Uruguay began the tournament with a 0–0 draw against [[France national football team|France]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round=249722/match=300061453/index.html |title=Uruguay draw a blank |work=FIFA.com |date=11 June 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813203358/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round%3D249722/match%3D300061453/index.html |archivedate=13 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> In the second match, a 3–0 win over [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]], Suárez drew a penalty and assisted [[Álvaro Pereira]]'s [[Stoppage time#Duration and tie-breaking methods|stoppage time]] goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round=249722/match=300061452/summary.html |title=Forlan silences South Africa |work=FIFA.com |date=16 June 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727000851/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round%3D249722/match%3D300061452/summary.html |archivedate=27 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> In the final match of the group stage, he headed in a goal off a pass from [[Edinson Cavani]] and was named [[Man of the Match]] in a 1–0 win over [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]].<ref name="FIFA Uru-Mex">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round=249722/match=300061450/summary.html |title=Uruguay edge Mexico, both advance |work=FIFA.com |date=22 June 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110808144502/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round%3D249722/match%3D300061450/summary.html |archivedate= 8 August 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Hassan">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_33/default.stm |title=Mexico 0–1 Uruguay |date=22 June 2010 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 June 2010 |first=Nabil |last=Hassan}}</ref> Uruguay won [[2010 FIFA World Cup Group A|Group A]] and advanced to the [[Single-elimination tournament|knockout stage]].<ref name="FIFA Uru-Mex"/><ref name="Hassan"/>
During the [[2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Round of 16|round of 16]] against [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]], Suárez scored both goals in a 2–1 win. His second broke a tie in the 80th minute when he dribbled around a defender and curled a "spectacular shot"<ref name="FIFA Uru-Kor">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round=249717/match=300061504/summary.html |title=Suarez double downs South Koreans |work=FIFA.com |date=26 June 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830110424/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round%3D249717/match%3D300061504/summary.html |archivedate=30 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> in off the far post; Suárez was again named Man of the Match.<ref name="FIFA Uru-Kor"/> This win put Uruguay through to the quarter-finals for the first time since [[1970 FIFA World Cup|1970]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_49/default.stm |title=Uruguay 2–1 South Korea |date=26 June 2010 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 June 2010|first=Saj |last=Chowdhury}}</ref> In the [[Uruguay v Ghana (2010)|quarter-final]] against [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]], the score was 1–1 at the end of regulation and the match went into [[Extra time#Association football|extra time]]. Late in extra time, Ghana sent a [[Direct free kick|free-kick]] into the box, and Suárez blocked [[Stephen Appiah]]'s shot on the goal line.<ref name="FIFA Uru-Gha">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round=249718/match=300061508/summary.html |title=Ghana pay the penalty |work=FIFA.com |date=2 July 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811165311/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round%3D249718/match%3D300061508/summary.html |archivedate=11 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> He then blocked [[Dominic Adiyiah]]'s goalbound header with his hands, committing a [[Professional foul#Association football|professional foul]]<ref name="Echo 2-3"/> to save what would have been the game winner<ref name="Hand of God">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2010/8785140.stm |title=World Cup 2010: I have hand of God – Uruguay's Suarez |work=BBC Sport |date=3 July 2010 |accessdate=24 August 2011}}</ref> and was sent off. [[Asamoah Gyan]] hit the crossbar with the ensuing [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty kick]]<ref name="FIFA Uru-Gha"/> and Suárez, who had stopped to watch, celebrated the miss before heading down the tunnel.<ref name="Marcus">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/03/sports/soccer/03ghanagame.html |title=Uruguay Trades Penalty for Chance at Victory |first=Jeffrey |last=Marcus |work=The New York Times |date=2 July 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011}}</ref><ref name="reuters">{{cite news |first=Angus |last=MacSwan |title=I had no choice but to handle says Uruguay's Suarez |publisher=Reuters |date=3 July 2010 |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-49856120100703 |accessdate=3 July 2010 }}</ref> Uruguay won the [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|shootout]] 4–2 and advanced to the semi-finals.<ref name="FIFA Uru-Gha"/>
{{quote box|width=27%|align=left|quote="The Hand of God now belongs to me. Mine is the real Hand of God."|source=—After using his hand in the quarter-final against Ghana, Suárez referred to [[Diego Maradona]]'s [[Argentina v England (1986 FIFA World Cup)#The "Hand of God"|”Hand of God” goal against England]] in [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986]].<ref>{{cite web |title=World Cup 2010: The Hand of God belongs to me, says Luis Suárez |work=The Guardian |date=3 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/jul/03/world-cup-2010-hand-god-suarez |accessdate=3 July 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=World Cup 2010: Uruguay striker Luis Suarez says it was 'Hand of God' against Ghana |work=The Telegraph |date=3 July 2010 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/uruguay/7869796/World-Cup-2010-Uruguay-striker-Luis-Suarez-says-it-was-Hand-of-God-against-Ghana.html |accessdate=3 July 2017 |author=Telegraph staff and agencies }}</ref>}} After the match, Suárez said, "I made the save of the tournament."<ref name="Hand of God"/> He said he had no alternative, was acting out of instinct, and would do it again if it helped his team win.<ref name="Doward">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/jul/04/luis-suarez-world-cup-villian-hand-of-god |title=Luis Suarez is new World Cup villain after 'hand of God' claim |first=Jamie |last=Doward |work=guardian.co.uk |date=4 July 2010 |accessdate=24 August 2011}}</ref> Ghana head coach [[Milovan Rajevac]] said the play was an "injustice"<ref name="Marcus"/> and Suárez was labelled a villain<ref name="Doward"/> and a cheat.<ref name="Jim White">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/world-cup-2010/7870325/World-Cup-2010-why-cant-football-tackle-cheats.html |title=World Cup 2010: why can't football tackle cheats? |first=Jim |last=White |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |work=The Telegraph |date=4 July 2010 |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> Others viewed him as a hero.<ref name="Echo 2-3"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://en.mercopress.com/2010/07/14/a-country-full-of-gratitude-defies-freezing-weather-to-honour-uruguay-s-soccer-team |title=A country full of gratitude defies freezing weather to honour Uruguay's soccer team |agency=MercoPress |date=14 July 2010 |accessdate=24 August 2011 }}</ref> Due to the automatic suspension that accompanies a red card, Suárez sacrificed himself in the semi-final for the unlikely chance the penalty would be missed, and his team would later win.<ref name="Lyttleton"/><ref name="Jim White"/>
While Suárez was suspended for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Uruguay vs Netherlands|semi-final]] match for his red card against Ghana,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/04/sports/soccer/04goal.html?scp=7&sq=Suarez+world+cup&st=nyt |title=Uruguay Star Won't Face Additional Sanctions for Handball |agency=Associated Press |work=New York Times |date=3 July 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011}}</ref> Uruguay "lacked a second striker <nowiki>[</nowiki>alongside [[Diego Forlán]]<nowiki>]</nowiki> of cunning and movement"<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/07/sports/soccer/07netherlandsside.html |title=Leader and Scorer, Yet Not a Finalist |first=Rob |last=Hughes |work=NYTimes.com|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=6 July 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011}}</ref> and lost 3–2 to the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round=249719/match=300061512/index.html |title=Oranje edge five-goal thriller |publisher=FIFA.com |date=6 July 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829052832/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round%3D249719/match%3D300061512/index.html |archivedate=29 August 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/07/sports/soccer/07netherlandsgame.html |title=Netherlands 3, Uruguay 2: A Flick of the Head, a Nod to the Past |first=Christopher |last=Clarey |work=New York Times |date=6 July 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011}}</ref> Suárez returned for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Third place play-off|third place game]] against [[Germany national football team|Germany]];
