he was booed almost every time he had the ball because of his handball in the Ghana match.<ref name="CNN 3rd place game">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/SPORT/football/07/10/world.cup.uruguay.germany/index.html |title=Khedira's late winner gives Germany third place at World Cup |date=10 July 2010 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |publisher=CNN}}</ref> He assisted Cavani on Uruguay's first goal,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round=249720/match=300061510/summary.html |title=Germany pip Uruguay to third place |work=FIFA.com |date=10 July 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425005150/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round%3D249720/match%3D300061510/summary.html |archivedate=25 April 2012 |df= }}</ref> but Uruguay lost 3–2.<ref name="CNN 3rd place game"/> During the tournament, Suárez played 543 minutes in six appearances and scored three goals.<ref name="9 Suarez overview">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/players/player=270775/index.html |title=9 Luis SUAREZ |work=FIFA.com |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519100547/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/players/player%3D270775/index.html |archivedate=19 May 2011 |df= }}</ref>
===2011 Copa América=== [[File:Luis Suarez - CA2011 mvp award (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Suárez was named most valuable player of the [[2011 Copa América]]]] In the [[2011 Copa América]] tournament, Suárez scored in Uruguay's opening game, a 1–1 draw with [[Peru national football team|Peru]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/05/sports/soccer/uruguay-rallies-to-tie-peru-in-copa-america.html |title= Uruguay Rallies to Tie Peru in Copa América |work=NYTimes.com|publisher= The New York Times Company|agency= Associated Press |date= 4 July 2011 |accessdate=26 August 2011}}</ref> Uruguay finished second in their group and advanced to the knockout round<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2011/07/13/liverpool-fc-striker-luis-suarez-helps-uruguay-reach-quarter-finals-of-copa-america-cup-with-1-0-win-over-mexico-100252-29044548/#ixzz1WCLYCjBE |title= Liverpool FC striker Luis Suarez helps Uruguay reach quarter-finals of Copa America Cup with 1–0 win over Mexico|publisher=Trinity Mirror |first= Paul |last=Snowdon |work= Liverpool Echo |date= 13 July 2011 |accessdate=26 August 2011}}</ref> with a win and two draws.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ca2011.com/selecoes_jogos.php?idS=c20ad4d76fe97759aa27a0c99bff6710 |title= Uruguay Matches |publisher= Copa América 2011 |work= CA2011.com |year= 2011 |accessdate= 26 August 2011 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121107004226/http://www.ca2011.com/selecoes_jogos.php?idS=c20ad4d76fe97759aa27a0c99bff6710 |archivedate= 7 November 2012 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> In the quarter-finals, Uruguay finished regulation and extra time tied at 1–1 with tournament hosts [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]]. Uruguay won the shootout 5–4 and Suárez converted his penalty.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ca2011.com/jogos_tabela.php?idJ=7f1171a78ce0780a2142a6eb7bc4f3c8 |title= Matches: Argentina v Uruguay |publisher= Copa América 2011 |work= CA2011.com |date= 16 July 2011 |accessdate= 26 August 2011 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110826032140/http://www.ca2011.com/jogos_tabela.php?idJ=7f1171a78ce0780a2142a6eb7bc4f3c8 |archivedate= 26 August 2011 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> Suárez scored both goals in Uruguay's 2–0 semi-final win over Peru and was named Man of the Match.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.fifa.com/confederationscup/news/newsid=1478029/index.html |title= Suarez sends Uruguay through |work= FIFA.com |date= 20 July 2011 |accessdate=26 August 2011}}</ref> In [[2011 Copa América Final|the final]], Suárez scored the first goal and Uruguay defeated [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]] 3–0 for their record 15th Copa América title.<ref name="CopaAmerica">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/jul/24/uruguay-paraguay-copa-america |title=Luis Suárez and Diego Forlán shoot Uruguay to record 15th Copa América |work=guardian.co.uk|publisher=Guardian News and Media |date= 24 July 2011 |accessdate=25 July 2011}}</ref> Suárez scored four goals<!-- Shootout goals don't count for total goals --> in the tournament and was named Player of the Tournament.<ref name="CopaAmerica"/><ref name="Liverpool profile"/>
===2012 Summer Olympics=== On 9 July 2012, Suárez was selected for the [[Uruguay Olympic football team]] alongside Liverpool teammate [[Sebastián Coates]] to compete in the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2012 Olympic Games]].<ref name="Olympic Games">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/olympics/18765459 |title=London 2012: Liverpool's Luis Suarez selected in Uruguay squad |work=[[BBC]] |date= 7 July 2012 |accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> In the first pre-tournament warm-up game against Chile, Suárez scored a hat-trick for Uruguay as they came from 0–2 down to win 6–4 in a thrilling match.<ref name="Uruguay vs Chile">{{cite news |url=http://en-maktoob.news.yahoo.com/suarez-hat-trick-uruguays-olympic-warm-win-054111541.html |title=Suarez hat-trick in Uruguay's Olympic warm-up win |work=Indo Asian News Service|publisher=Yahoo |date= 11 July 2012 |accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref>
As one of Uruguay's three overage players, Suárez was named as captain for the Olympic Games.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/jul/24/football-liverpool-luis-suarez |title=London 2012: Luiz Suárez back at Old Trafford to lead Uruguay | Football |publisher=The Guardian |date= 24 July 2012|accessdate=8 August 2013}}</ref> After an opening win over the [[United Arab Emirates national under-23 football team|United Arab Emirates]], Uruguay were defeated by [[Senegal national under-23 football team|Senegal]] and [[Great Britain Olympic football team|Great Britain]] and eliminated at the first round. Suárez failed to score during the tournament.
===2013 Confederations Cup=== Suárez was selected in the Uruguay squad to play in Brazil at the [[2013 FIFA Confederations Cup|2013 Confederations Cup]]. He scored a curling free-kick from {{convert|30|yd}} in a 2–1 defeat to [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in their opening match at [[Recife]] on 16 June.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22900978 |title=Spain 2–1 Uruguay |first=Neil |last=Johnston |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 June 2013 |accessdate=31 August 2014}}</ref> He then scored twice after appearing as a substitute in Uruguay's 8–0 win over [[Tahiti national football team|Tahiti]], making him the Uruguay national team's all-time [[Uruguay national football team#Records|top-goalscorer]] with 35 goals, surpassing his teammate Diego Forlán.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Yorke|first1=Graeme|title=Uruguay 8 Tahiti 0: Suarez becomes record scorer after netting double against minnows|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2347059/Uruguay-8-Tahiti-0-Luis-Suarez-record-scorer-netting-double-minnows.html|accessdate=6 July 2015|work=Daily Mail|date=23 June 2013}}</ref> Uruguay were eventually eliminated in the semi-finals, losing 2–1 to [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in [[Belo Horizonte]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23026063 "Brazil 2–1 Uruguay"]. BBC Sport. Retrieved 29 June 2014</ref>
===2014 FIFA World Cup, third biting incident=== [[File:FIFA World Cup 2014 - Uruguay 2 - England 1 - 140619-6454-jikatu (14282608880).jpg|thumb|left|Suárez (middle) [[Goal celebration|celebrating]] one of his two goals against [[England national football team|England]] at the 2014 World Cup]] Suárez ended the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification|2014 World Cup qualification]] campaign as [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)#Goalscorers|top scorer]] in the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|South American section]] with 11 goals.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/southamerica/statistics/topscorers.html|title=Top scorers|accessdate=16 October 2013|work=FIFA}}</ref> In November 2013, Uruguay defeated [[Jordan national football team|Jordan]] 5–0 on aggregate in an [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC – CONMEBOL play-off)|intercontinental play-off]] to qualify for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25027589|title=World Cup 2014: Uruguay clinch final spot with Jordan win|date=21 November 2013|accessdate=6 December 2013|work=BBC}}</ref>
On 22 May, Suárez underwent emergency surgery on his left knee. He was confined to a wheelchair for a time, leading to rumours he would be unable to participate in the World Cup.<ref>{{cite web|title=England's World Cup all but over as they lose to Uruguay|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/10913384/Englands-World-Cup-all-but-over-as-they-lose-to-Uruguay.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=19 June 2014|date=19 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/may/22/luis-suarez-world-cup-doubt-uruguay-knee-operation|title=Uruguay confident Luis Suárez will make World Cup despite knee surgery|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=United Kingdom|accessdate=20 June 2014|date=22 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/310345.html|title=Missing World Cup would kill Suarez – Gerrard |publisher=ESPN|accessdate=20 June 2014|date=25 May 2014}}</ref> He was named as a substitute for Uruguay's first match, a 3–1 defeat to [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]], but did not play in the match. Suárez started Uruguay's second match against [[England national football team|England]] and scored both of the team's goals in a 2–1 win at the [[Arena Corinthians]] in [[São Paulo]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25285176 "Uruguay 2–1 England"]. BBC Sport. Retrieved 26 June 2014</ref>
{{Quote box|width=27%|align=right|quote="These are just things that happen out on the pitch. It was just the two of us inside the area and he bumped into me with his shoulder and that's how my eye got like this as well. There are things that happen on the pitch and you should not make such a big deal out of them."|source=— Suárez's post-match interview against Italy, 24 June 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Suarez claims 'these things happen' in biting row|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/318665.html|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref>}} {{Quote box|width=27%|align=right|quote="... I lost my balance ... falling on top of my opponent ... I hit my face against [Chiellini], leaving a small bruise on my cheek and a strong pain in my teeth."|source=— Suárez's defence to the FIFA Disciplinary Committee, 25 June.<ref name="lostbalance"/>}} {{Quote box|width=27%|align=right|quote="... the truth is that my colleague Giorgio Chiellini suffered the physical result of a bite in the collision he suffered with me ... I apologize to Giorgio Chiellini and the entire football family. I vow to the public that there will never again be another incident like [this]."|source=— Suárez on 30 June 2014.<ref name="Suarez apology Twitter"/>}}
For Uruguay's final group match against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] on 24 June, Uruguay needed a win to advance to the [[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage|knockout stage]] while Italy only needed a draw.<ref>{{cite web|title=Italy – Uruguay Preview: Guaranteed exit for a former world champion|url=http://www.goal.com/en-india/match/italy-vs-uruguay/1220093/preview|website=Goal.com|first=Luis |last=Herrera|accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref> Around the 79th minute and with the score at 0–0, Suárez clashed with Italian defender [[Giorgio Chiellini]] while waiting for a cross. Replays showed that Suárez lunged at Chiellini and bit his shoulder (Chiellini showed bite marks), followed by Suárez falling and clutching his face.<ref name="Menezes"/><ref name="bite row"/> The controversial incident made headline news around the world.<ref>[https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/luis-suarez-bite-we-will-use-every-argument-possible-to-get-him-cleared-vows-lawyer-9562704.html "Luis Suarez bite: We will use every argument possible to get him cleared, vows lawyer"]. Evening Standard. Retrieved 6 September 2014</ref> As the Italian players protested to Mexican referee [[Marco Antonio Rodríguez]] for not penalising Suárez for the bite, Uruguay won a corner and scored. The match would finish 1–0 to Uruguay as they qualified for the knockout stage and eliminated Italy.<ref name="Menezes">{{cite news |last=De Menezes |first=Jack |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/worldcup/luis-suarez-bite-uruguay-striker-accused-of-biting-giorgio-chiellini-in-latest-controversy-during-world-cup-clash-9560650.html |title=Luis Suarez bite: Uruguay striker accused of biting Giorgio Chiellini in latest controversy during World Cup clash |publisher=[[The Independent]] |date=24 June 2014 |accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref><ref name="bite row">{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/318587.html |title=Suarez at centre of new biting row as Uruguay progress |publisher=ESPN |date=24 June 2014 |accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Ogden |first=Mark |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25285368 |title=Italy 0 Uruguay 1 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=24 June 2014 |accessdate=25 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140705095346/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25285368 |archivedate=5 July 2014}}</ref>
Two days later, on 26 June, the [[FIFA Disciplinary Code|FIFA Disciplinary Committee]], banned Suárez for nine international matches, effective immediately, meaning he would take no further part in the World Cup. The ban ruled him out of [[2015 Copa América]] as well. It was the longest such ban in World Cup history, exceeding the eight-match ban handed to Italy's [[Mauro Tassotti]] for breaking the nose of Spain's Luis Enrique at the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994 World Cup]].<ref name="Ban2014"/><ref name="Luis Suarez suspended">{{cite news|title=Luis Suárez banned for four months for biting in World Cup game|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jun/26/world-cup-luis-suarez-ban-biting-uruguay|accessdate=26 June 2014|publisher=The Guardian|date=26 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/2014-world-cup-fifa-bans-suarez-games-months/story?id=24314667|title=FIFA Suspends and Fines Suarez for 9 Games and 4 Months After Biting Player|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=26 June 2014}}</ref> He was also banned from taking part in any football-related activity (including entering any stadium) for four months and fined [[Swiss franc|CHF]]100,000.<ref name="FIFABan"/><ref name="Ban2014"/><ref name="Luis Suarez suspended"/> The seven-member FIFA panel studied the incident from 34 camera angles and rejected Suárez's defence that the bite was as a result of an accidental collision, instead finding the bite was "deliberate, intentional and without provocation... with the intention of wounding [Chiellini] or at least of destabilising him". The severity of the penalty was due to the fact it was Suárez's third biting offence, as well as what FIFA saw as a lack of remorse.<ref name="lostbalance">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jun/28/luis-suarez-bite-balance-hit-face-chiellini|title=Luis Suárez bite defence: I lost balance and hit my teeth against Chiellini|last=Gibson|first=Owen|date=28 June 2014|work=The Observer|accessdate=29 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140711010720/http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jun/28/luis-suarez-bite-balance-hit-face-chiellini|archivedate=11 July 2014}}</ref> Soon after the suspension was announced, online gambling firm [[888poker]] cancelled its sponsorship deal with Suárez.<ref>{{cite web|title=Luis Suarez bite: Uruguay striker loses backing of gambling firm|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28053513|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=28 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140709170401/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28053513|archivedate=9 July 2014}}</ref> With Suárez banned, Uruguay lost their next match 0–2 to Colombia and were eliminated from the World Cup.<ref>{{cite web|title=James Rodriguez scores twice, lifts Colombia to first quarterfinal|url=https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2014/06/28/colombia-uruguay-world-cup-commentary-recap-knockout-stage|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref>
On the same day the ban was announced, the [[Uruguayan Football Association]] (AUF) said it would appeal the suspension.<ref name="Uruguay to appeal Suarez ban for biting"/> Suárez's lawyer said that "we don't have any doubts" of a European-based campaign against Suárez.<ref>{{cite web|title=Luis Suarez: Uruguay captain Lugano dismisses 'bite' claims|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28026610|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=27 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140705044030/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28026610|archivedate=5 July 2014}}</ref> Various Uruguayan individuals defended Suárez, questioning if he had actually bitten Chiellini, and criticised the severity of his ban, including [[President of Uruguay]] [[José Mujica]], who labelled the ban "[[Fascism|fascist]]" and called FIFA "a bunch of old sons of bitches";<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/26/us-soccer-world-suarez-president-idUSKBN0F101O20140626|title=Leave Suarez alone, Uruguay president urges|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=29 June 2014|last=Schreiber|first=Irene|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626073010/https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/26/us-soccer-world-suarez-president-idUSKBN0F101O20140626|archivedate=26 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Luis Suarez bite ban: Uruguay President Jose Mujica insults Fifa|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28085880|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=30 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701131027/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28085880|archivedate=1 July 2014}}</ref> AUF president Wilmar Valdez;<ref name="Uruguay to appeal Suarez ban for biting">{{cite news|title=Uruguay to appeal Suarez ban for biting|url=http://www.dw.de/uruguay-to-appeal-suarez-ban-for-biting/a-17739744|accessdate=26 June 2014|publisher=Deutsche Welle|date=26 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627111401/http://www.dw.de/uruguay-to-appeal-suarez-ban-for-biting/a-17739744|archivedate=27 June 2014}}</ref> Uruguay captain [[Diego Lugano]];<ref>{{cite web|title=World Cup 2014: How Uruguay closed ranks over Luis Suarez|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28029656|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=27 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140710134942/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28029656|archivedate=10 July 2014}}</ref> and Uruguay head coach Óscar Tabárez, who resigned from two FIFA posts in protest of the ban.<ref name="reactions">{{cite web|title=Luis Suarez: Uruguay coach Oscar Tabarez to quit Fifa posts|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28058345|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=28 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140630080740/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28058345|archivedate=30 June 2014}}</ref> The Uruguayan media were also noted to have been in a defiant and defensive mood.<ref>{{cite web|title=Luis Suarez: global scrutiny after Giorgio Chiellini 'bite'|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28015683|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=27 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626212347/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28015683|archivedate=26 June 2014}}</ref> For non-Uruguayan parties, Chiellini, who was bitten, called the ban "excessive", while international players' union [[FIFPro]] called for Suárez to "receive all the support he needs" and that the "focus should be on the rehabilitation and serious treatment" of Suárez.<ref name="reactions"/>
Six days after the incident, on 30 June, Suárez apologised to Chiellini through Twitter and vowed never to repeat the incident, while writing that the "physical result of a bite" occurred in a collision with Chiellini.<ref name="Suarez apology Twitter">{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/luis16suarez/status/483659463417548800 |title=Suárez's official apology |publisher=[[Twitter]] |first=Luis |last=Suárez |date=30 June 2014 |accessdate=30 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701015706/https://twitter.com/luis16suarez/status/483659463417548800|archivedate=1 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="Suarez apology The Guardian">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jun/30/luis-suarez-apologises-giorgio-chiellini-bite |title=Luis Suárez apologises to Giorgio Chiellini for World Cup bite |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |last=Lucas |first=Dan |date=30 June 2014 |accessdate=30 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707180448/http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jun/30/luis-suarez-apologises-giorgio-chiellini-bite |archivedate=7 July 2014}}</ref> Chiellini responded through Twitter indicating all was forgotten and his hope that FIFA would reduce Suárez's suspension.<ref name="Suarez apology The Guardian"/><ref name="Chiellini response Twitter">{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/chiellini/status/483671807380443136 |title=Chiellini's Twitter response |publisher=[[Twitter]] |first=Giorgio |last=Chiellini |date=30 June 2014 |accessdate=30 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701235301/https://twitter.com/chiellini/status/483671807380443136 |archivedate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
On 3 July, the AUF appealed Suárez's ban,<ref name="AUF appeal">{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12040/9370577/world-cup-uruguay-launch-suarez-appeal |title=World Cup: FIFA confirm Uruguay have appealed against Luis Suarez’s biting ban |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=3 July 2014 |accessdate=3 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="Suarez suspended while appeal is pending">{{cite news|url=http://www.courant.com/sports/world-cup/hc-luis-suarez-suspended-0627-20140626,0,2075182.story |title=Luis Suarez's Bite Results in Nine-Match Ban; Uruguay Will Appeal |newspaper=[[Hartford Courant]] |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=26 June 2014 |accessdate=3 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707191830/http://www.courant.com/sports/world-cup/hc-luis-suarez-suspended-0627-20140626%2C0%2C2075182.story |archivedate= 7 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> but it was rejected by FIFA on 10 July.<ref name="Suarez appeal rejected FIFA">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2014/m=7/news=appeals-of-suarez-and-the-uruguayan-fa-rejected-sanctions-upheld-2403024.html |title=Appeals of Suarez and the Uruguayan FA rejected, sanctions upheld |publisher=[[FIFA]] |date=10 July 2014 |accessdate=10 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140711041429/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y%3D2014/m%3D7/news%3Dappeals-of-suarez-and-the-uruguayan-fa-rejected-sanctions-upheld-2403024.html |archivedate=11 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="Suarez appeal rejected BBC">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28251964 |title=Luis Suarez's appeal against bite ban rejected by Fifa |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=10 July 2014 |accessdate=10 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140711042532/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28251964 |archivedate=11 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="Suarez appeal rejected Sky Sports">{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12040/9378008/fifa-rejects-luis-suarez-appeal-against-ban-for-biting-giorgio-chiellini |title=FIFA rejects Luis Suarez appeal against ban for biting Giorgio Chiellini |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=10 July 2014 |accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref> With Suárez's ban not preventing him from [[Transfer (association football)|transferring]] to another club,<ref name="Suarez no transfer ban">{{cite web |url=http://www.itv.com/worldcup/liverpool-keep-counsel-over-suarez-ban-reaction |title=Liverpool keep counsel over Suarez ban reaction |work=[[ITV News]] |date=26 June 2014 |accessdate=26 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626233554/http://www.itv.com/worldcup/liverpool-keep-counsel-over-suarez-ban-reaction |archivedate=26 June 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> it was announced on 11 July that Suárez had agreed to move to Barcelona.<ref name="BBCpootobar">{{cite news|title=Luis Suarez: Liverpool & Barcelona agree deal for striker|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28180600|accessdate=11 July 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 July 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712035115/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28180600|archivedate=12 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="Suarez Barcelona transfer official">{{cite web |url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/fc-barcelona-and-liverpool-fc-have-reached-an-agreement-for-the-transfer-of-luis-suarez |title=FC Barcelona and Liverpool FC have reached an agreement for the transfer of Luis Suárez |publisher=[[FC Barcelona]] |date=11 July 2014 |accessdate=11 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712034551/http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/fc-barcelona-and-liverpool-fc-have-reached-an-agreement-for-the-transfer-of-luis-suarez |archivedate=12 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="Suarez Barcelona transfer Liverpool">{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/166178-lfc-statement-suarez-to-leave |title=LFC statement: Suarez to leave |publisher=[[Liverpool F.C.]] |date=11 July 2014 |accessdate=11 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140711215817/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/166178-lfc-statement-suarez-to-leave |archivedate=11 July 2014}}</ref> Days before the transfer, Suárez's apology to Chiellini had been praised by various Barcelona club individuals. Barcelona club president [[Josep Maria Bartomeu]] said the apology was "honourable", sporting director [[Andoni Zubizarreta]] welcomed Suárez as being "humble enough to admit an error" while new signing [[Ivan Rakitić]] commended Suárez's "character and strength".<ref>{{cite web|title=Barcelona claim Suarez is 'humble'|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/320565.html|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=12 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Luis Suarez: Barcelona will meet Liverpool striker's release clause|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28112887|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=12 July 2014}}</ref>
===Copa América Centenario and 2018 FIFA World Cup=== [[File:Luis Suárez Uruguay.jpg|thumb|upright|Suárez playing against [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] in the last 16 of the 2018 World Cup]] On 25 March 2016, after over a year of international absence for Uruguay, Suárez scored an equalizer against Brazil in [[Recife]] for a 2–2 draw in the [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|qualification process]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Beesley|first1=Chris|title=Ex-Liverpool FC striker Luis Suarez points to 'suffering' on scoring return|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/ex-liverpool-fc-striker-luis-11098676|accessdate=26 March 2016|work=Liverpool Echo|date=26 March 2016}}</ref> Suárez was included in Uruguay's 23-man squad for the [[Copa América Centenario]], although a hamstring injury sustained in the 2016 Copa del Rey final on 22 May put his place in the team in jeopardy.<ref name="Suárez set to miss start of Copa América"/><ref name="hamstring injury"/> Although he remained in the squad, he missed both of his national side's opening group losses to Mexico and [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]], which resulted in a first-round elimination from the tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/09/venezuela-uruguay-copa-america-quarter-finals|title=Luis Suárez fumes as Venezuela dump Uruguay out of Copa América|publisher=The Guardian|date=10 June 2016|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> He was once again left on the substitutes' bench in Uruguay's final 3–0 group win over [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] on 13 June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/luis-suarez-s-uruguay-bow-out-of-copa-america-with-3-0-defeat-of-jamaica|title=Luis Suárez's Uruguay bow out of Copa America with 3–0 defeat of Jamaica|publisher=FC Barcelona|date=14 June 2016|accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> [[File:2018 FIFA World Cup Group A march URU-KSA - Man of the match.jpg|thumb|left|Suárez named man of the match on the big screen for his display against [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]] at the 2018 World Cup]] Suárez scored twice on 10 October 2017 as Uruguay won 4–2 at home to [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia]] in their final World Cup qualifying match, thus securing their place for the tournament in Russia.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jukic |first1=Ante |title=Uruguay 4 Bolivia 2: Suarez and Cavani show their class |url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/8/main/2017/10/11/39312952/uruguay-4-bolivia-2-suarez-and-cavani-show-their-class |accessdate=20 June 2018 |date=10 October 2017}}</ref> In March, Uruguay won the [[2018 China Cup]], and Suárez scored his [[List of association football players with 50 or more international goals|50th international goal]] with a penalty against the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] in the semi-finals, winning it himself when fouled by goalkeeper [[Jiří Pavlenka]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Suarez bags 50th Uruguay goal in win over Czechs |url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-soccer-chinacup-ury-cze/suarez-bags-50th-uruguay-goal-in-win-over-czechs-idUKKBN1GZ2L0 |accessdate=20 June 2018 |publisher=Reuters |date=23 March 2018}}</ref> He won his [[List of association football players with 100 or more caps|100th cap]] on 20 June 2018 in Uruguay's second group match at the World Cup, scoring the only goal against [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]] at the [[Rostov Arena]] in [[Rostov-on-Don]] to advance the nation into the last 16.<ref>{{cite news |title=Luis Suarez nudges unconvincing Uruguay into second round as Saudi Arabia slump out |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/world-cup/2018/06/20/uruguay-vs-saudi-arabia-world-cup-2018-live-score-latest-updates/ |accessdate=20 June 2018 |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=20 June 2018}}</ref> In the final group game on 25 June, Suárez scored Uruguay’s opener with a free kick into the bottom corner in a 3–0 win over hosts [[Russia national football team|Russia]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Suarez and Cavani score as Uruguay beat Russia to win Group A |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44439221 |agency=BBC |date=25 June 2018}}</ref> In the Round of 16 match against [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] on 30 June, he set-up Cavani's opening goal in an eventual 2–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jun/30/uruguay-portugal-world-cup-last-16-match-report |title=Edinson Cavani sends Uruguay to World Cup last eight as Portugal bow out|publisher=The Guardian |date=29 June 2018 }}</ref> Uruguay were eliminated from the tournament following a 2–0 defeat to France in the quarter-finals on 6 July.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bevan |first1=Chris |title=Uruguay 0 France 2 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44652179 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=6 July 2018 |location=Nizhny Novgorod |date=6 July 2018}}</ref>
==Style of play== [[File:Luis Suarez runs at Distin 3.jpg|thumb|Suárez in action for Liverpool takes on [[Sylvain Distin]] of [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] during the [[Merseyside Derby]] in 2012]] Suárez creates goal scoring chances with his powerful shot,<ref name="9 Suarez profile">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/players/player=270775/profile.html |title=9 Luis SUAREZ – Profile |work=FIFA.com |accessdate=23 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110502061805/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/players/player%3D270775/profile.html |archivedate=2 May 2011 |df=}}</ref> and has "remarkable technical ability" according to his [[FIFA]] profile.<ref name="9 Suarez profile" /><ref name="soccernet stats">{{cite web |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/players/stats?id=125088&league=NED.1&season=2009 |title=Luis Suárez Statistics |accessdate=13 April 2010 |publisher=ESPN Soccernet}}</ref> Known for his direct running at players, Suárez has a particular penchant for [[Nutmeg (football)|nutmegging]] opponents (putting the ball through their legs).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Collins|first1=Neil|title=Make Us Dream: A Fan's View of the 2013/14 Season|date=5 July 2014|publisher=Lulu|page=108}}</ref> Liverpool fans (accompanied with a banner) used to say he was so good, "he could nutmeg a mermaid".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sportsjoe.ie/football/he-can-nutmeg-a-mermaid-but-luis-suarez-really-cant-wave-81278|title=Watch: He can nutmeg a mermaid, but Luis Suarez really can't wave |agency=Sports.Joe.ie. |date=21 June 2018}}</ref> [[Harry Redknapp]] said that Suárez could play anywhere – as the [[Centre forward|target man]] or behind as a [[Forward (association football)#Second striker|second striker]]. Uruguay head coach Óscar Tabárez called Suárez "a great forward, an elite player among forwards in the world",<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/2011-07-19-1300813299_x.htm |title=Suarez's 2 goals put Uruguay into final |first=Vicente L. |last=Panetta |work=USA Today |agency=Associated Press |date=19 July 2011 |accessdate=6 November 2011}}</ref> and Liverpool coach Kenny Dalglish said, "he's intelligent, he's had a fantastic education at Ajax".<ref name="Rice Dalglish">{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/latest-news/kenny-suarez-deal-a-statement |title=Kenny: Suarez deal a statement |first=Jimmy |last=Rice |date=1 February 2011 |publisher=Liverpool FC |work=LiverpoolFC.TV |accessdate=22 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829051000/http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/latest-news/kenny-suarez-deal-a-statement |archivedate=29 August 2011 |df=}}</ref> Former Liverpool striker [[John Aldridge]] said his abilities allow him to get into a position to score<ref name="Aldridge page 2">{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2011/09/27/john-aldridge-too-early-to-crown-luis-suarez-a-liverpool-fc-legend-100252-29492675/2/ |first=John |last=Aldridge |title=Too early to crown Luis Suarez a Liverpool FC legend |page=2 |work=Liverpool Echo|publisher=Trinity Mirror |date=27 September 2011 |accessdate=2 October 2011}}</ref> and evade defenders.<ref name="Aldridge page 3">{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2011/09/27/john-aldridge-too-early-to-crown-luis-suarez-a-liverpool-fc-legend-100252-29492675/3/ |first=John |last=Aldridge |title=Too early to crown Luis Suarez a Liverpool FC legend |page=3 |work=Liverpool Echo|publisher=Trinity Mirror |date=27 September 2011 |accessdate=2 October 2011}}</ref> Suárez has been praised for his [[work rate]],<ref name="Aldridge page 3" /> and his quickness<ref name="Rice Dalglish" /> that allows him to attack from the outside.<ref name="soccernet stats" /> He also creates scoring opportunities for his teammates.<ref name="9 Suarez overview" />
Former Ajax coach [[Marco van Basten]] criticised Suárez for his tendency to receive yellow cards.<ref name="Echo 2-1" /> Van Basten said he had a tense relationship with Suárez,<ref name="Echo 2-1" /> although he conceded, "Luis is unpredictable, he's hard to influence but that makes him special."<ref name="Echo 2-1" /> At times, Suárez can be dominant but fail to convert his efforts into goals.<ref name="Hubbard">{{cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story/_/id/978528/norman-hubbard:-counting-the-cost-at-liverpool |title=Counting the cost at Liverpool |first=Norman |last=Hubbard |publisher=ESPN Soccernet |date=3 November 2011 |accessdate=6 November 2011}}</ref> Despite his weaknesses, Suárez's leadership stood out to Ajax management.<ref name="Echo 2-4">{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/everton-fc/everton-fc-news/2011/02/10/the-luis-suarez-story-part-two-new-liverpool-fc-star-always-one-to-hit-the-headlines-100252-28146234/4/ |title=The Luis Suarez story part two – new Liverpool FC star always one to hit the headlines |work=Liverpool Echo|publisher=Trinity Mirror |date=10 February 2011 |accessdate=23 August 2011 |page=4}}</ref>
== Controversies == Suárez has been widely accused of [[Diving (association football)|diving]].{{refn|group=note|<ref name="doeshedive">{{cite web|title=World Cup: England striker Daniel Sturridge insists he won't cheat to win|url=http://www1.skysports.com/FIFA-World-Cup-2014/news/12016/9351408/world-cup-england-striker-daniel-sturridge-insists-he-wont-cheat-to-win|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Hunter|first=Andy|title=Liverpool's Luis Suárez has a history of diving, says David Moyes |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/oct/26/everton-david-moyes-liverpool-luis-suarez|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=19 January 2013|date=26 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Luis Suarez 'diving' debate continues|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/1185009/liverpool's-brendan-rodgers-defends-luis-suarez's-'diving'?|work=[[ESPN FC]]|accessdate=19 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho accuses Luis Suarez of diving|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25545739|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref>}} His manager, teammates and various analysts have commented that this reputation for simulation has caused referees not to award him legitimate penalties.<ref>{{cite news|last=Percy|first=John|title=Luis Suárez is the victim of a referee witch-hunt over unfair reputation for diving, say Liverpool team-mates |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/9563720/Luis-Suarez-is-the-victim-of-a-referee-witch-hunt-over-unfair-reputation-for-diving-say-Liverpool-team-mates.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|accessdate=19 January 2013|date=24 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Lacey|first=David|title=A reputation for diving is hard for referees to forget in a hurry|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2012/oct/05/luis-suarez-dives-referees|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=19 January 2013|date=5 October 2012}}</ref> In January 2013, Suárez admitted to diving against Stoke City in an October 2012 match. This led his manager Brendan Rodgers to comment his actions were "unacceptable" and that he would be dealt with "internally" by the club.<ref>{{cite web|title=Luis Suarez diving: Liverpool boss Brendan Rodgers reveals anger |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21064709|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=19 January 2013}}</ref> Suárez has also been accused of [[Stomp (strike)|stamping]] on opponents in the Premier League and the UEFA Europa League.<ref>{{cite web|title=Luis Suarez accused of stamping by Wigan boss Roberto Martinez |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/20381086|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Everton v Liverpool: Luis Suárez is Anfield's inspiration but a pantomime villain to away fans|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/9639691/Everton-v-Liverpool-Luis-Suarez-is-Anfields-inspiration-but-a-pantomime-villain-to-away-fans.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=27 June 2014|first=Jim |last=White}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Uefa says no investigation over Luis Suárez 'stamp' against Zenit|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/feb/26/luis-suarez-liverpool-zenit-stamp|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref> In December 2013, Spanish football website ''El Gol Digital'' ranked Suárez at fifth in its list of the world's dirtiest footballers.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/soccer/kevin-muscat-named-footballs-dirtiest-player-20131212-2z8r4.html |title=Kevin Muscat named football's dirtiest player |first=Dominic |last=Bossi |newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald |date=12 December 2013 |accessdate=31 August 2014}}</ref> During the 2018 World Cup game against Portugal, after collisions with Portuguese players, Suarez twice acted like he had a head injury despite Suarez's head not being touched.<ref>{{cite web |title=Luis Suarez back to his tenacious best as Uruguay beat Portugal |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12098/11422374/luis-suarez-back-to-his-tenacious-best-as-uruguay-beat-portugal |publisher=[[ESPN]] |accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref>
==Media and sponsorship==
[[File:Suarez training Ajax.JPG|thumb|upright|Suárez is sponsored by [[Adidas]]. He wears Adidas X 18 football boots.]] Suárez has a sponsorship deal with German sportswear and equipment supplier [[Adidas]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/christinasettimi/2014/06/26/world-cup-with-freedom-to-transfer-and-adidas-deal-intact-ban-wont-hurt-luis-suarez-financially/ |title= World Cup: With Freedom To Transfer and Adidas Deal Intact, Bite Ban Won't Hurt Luis Suarez Financially |publisher=Forbes |accessdate=8 September 2014}}</ref> Suárez starred in a 2014 advert for [[Beats Electronics|Beats]] with other global football stars including Neymar and [[Thierry Henry]], with the theme of "The Game Before the Game" and the players' pre-game ritual of listening to music.<ref>[https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/neymar-thierry-henry-and-luis-suarez-star-in-thrilling-new-world-cup-advert-9495497.html "Neymar, Thierry Henry and Luis Suarez star in thrilling new World Cup advert"]. Evening Standard. Retrieved 5 September 2014</ref> In Uruguay, Suárez has also appeared in advertisements for Abitab, [[Antel]], [[Cablevisión (Argentina)|Cablevisión]], [[Garnier]], [[Pepsi]] and [[Samsung]].<ref>[http://www.referi.uy/cuestion-imagen-n225079 Cuestión de imagen] – Jorge Señorans, Referí, 30 May 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.elobservador.com.uy/la-evolucion-actoral-luis-suarez-seis-publicidades-n902269 La evolución actoral de Luis Suárez en seis publicidades] – Facundo Macchi, El Observador, 26 April 2016</ref>
Suárez features in [[EA Sports]]' [[FIFA (video game series)|''FIFA'' video game series]]: in keeping close to the real life game Suárez‘s ban for his bite on Giorgio Chiellini at the 2014 World Cup was replicated in ''[[FIFA 15]]'', with the player unavailable for gamers to select until his ban ended on 26 October.<ref>{{cite news |title=Luis Suarez is banned from playing for Barcelona in FIFA 15 until 26 October |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/gaming/luis-suarez-is-banned-from-playing-for-barcelona-in-fifa-15-until-26-october-9753242.html |work=The Independent |date=21 June 2018}}</ref>
Active on social media, Suárez has [[List of most-followed Instagram accounts|over 28 million Instagram followers]], the most for a person from Uruguay.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://socialblade.com/instagram/top/100/followers|title=Top 100 Instagram Users by Followers- Socialblade Instagram Stats – Instagram Statistics|work=Socialblade|accessdate=October 3, 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Suárez was born in [[Salto, Uruguay]], the fourth of seven boys.<ref name="Lyttleton"/><ref name="Pearce 1-1">{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-fc/lfc-player-profiles/luis-suarez/2011/02/09/luis-suarez-s-rise-from-the-streets-of-montevideo-to-liverpool-fc-hero-part-one-100252-28138725/ |title=Luis Suarez's rise from the streets of Montevideo to Liverpool FC hero – part one |first=James |last=Pearce |newspaper=Liverpool Echo |date=9 February 2011 |accessdate=20 August 2011 |page=1 }}</ref> His older brother, [[Paolo Suárez]], is also a professional footballer, currently playing for [[A.D. Isidro Metapán|Isidro Metapán]] in El Salvador.
Suárez moved with his family to [[Montevideo, Uruguay|Montevideo]] when he was seven, and his parents separated when he was nine.<ref name="Pearce 1-1"/> In Montevideo, he developed his football skills on the streets,<ref name="personal bio"/><ref name="Pearce 1-1"/> while also taking up work as a street sweeper.<ref name="ESPNportrait"/> The contrast between his life in Europe and the poverty he left behind has been cited as contributing to his periodic aggression on the field, as well as being a possible explanation for the more forgiving attitudes of the Uruguayan public and press towards such cases, compared to Europe.<ref name="ESPNportrait"/>
[[File:Mural escuela 171 01.jpg|thumb|left|Mural of Suárez on his former school in Montevideo, Uruguay]] Suárez is of [[Multiracial|mixed race]], with public records indicating his having a [[black people|black]] grandfather.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16277126 |title=Liverpool statement on Luis Suarez ban in full |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=20 December 2011 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> The matter of ethnicity was raised in reporting on the [[Luis Suárez#Racial abuse incident|Patrice Evra incident]], where use by his grandmother, Lila Piriz, of "''mi negrito''" as a sobriquet has been offered to explain Suárez's repeated use of "negro" over the two-minute altercation; the FA judged his evidence unreliable ''en route'' to issuing him an eight-match ban.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/sports/luis-suarez-s-granny-used-to-call-him-mi-negrito-news-news-mc0skdecaig.html |title=Luis Suarez's granny used to call him 'Mi Negrito' |publisher=Sify.com |date=26 February 2012 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref>
Suárez began dating Sofía Balbi at age 15 in Montevideo; the Balbi family moved to [[Barcelona]] in 2003, and Suárez's focus on football strengthened as a result as he wanted to follow them to Europe to join Sofía again.<ref name="ESPNportrait"/> Suárez married her in 2009, and the couple have a daughter and a son.<ref name="Lyttleton"/><ref name="daughter">{{cite web|url=http://www.vi.nl/Nieuws-item/184887/Suarez-in-Barcelona-vader-geworden-van-dochter.htm |title=Suarez in Barcelona vader geworden van dochter |publisher=Voetbal International |date=5 August 2010 |accessdate=6 August 2010 |language=Dutch |trans-title=Suarez has a daughter in Barcelona |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806171323/http://www.vi.nl/Nieuws-item/184887/Suarez-in-Barcelona-vader-geworden-van-dochter.htm |archivedate=6 August 2010 }}</ref> He has a tattoo of his daughter’s name Delfina on his wrist which he kisses as part of his [[goal celebration]] – this celebration routine is featured in EA Sports’ video game ''[[FIFA 15]]''.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/luis-suarez-reveals-double-meaning-of-trademark-goal-celebration-8457435.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title=Luis Suarez reveals double meaning of trademark goal celebration | date=18 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Watch Samuel Eto'o's old man celebration and more in the FIFA 15 goal celebration tutorial video |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/soccer-dirty-tackle/samuel-eto-o-s-old-man-celebration-and-more-to-be-featured-in-fifa-15-182936039.html |accessdate=14 October 2018 |agency=Yahoo.com}}</ref> On 11 July 2014, Suárez joined Barcelona, allowing him to live closer with his wife Sofía's family. On the move, Suárez said, "[Liverpool] did all they could to get me to stay, but playing and living in Spain, where my wife's family live, is a lifelong dream and ambition. I believe now the timing is right."<ref>{{cite news|title=Luis Suarez: Liverpool & Barcelona agree £75m deal for striker|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28180600|accessdate=13 July 2014|publisher=BBC Sports|date=11 July 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714183012/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28180600|archivedate=14 July 2014}}</ref> In 2014, Suárez released his autobiography, ''Crossing the Line – My Story''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Luis Suarez: Crossing the Line – My Story|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Luis-Suarez-Crossing-Line-Story/dp/147222423X|publisher=Amazon UK|accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref>

{{Infobox royalty|consort=yes | succession = [[Holy Roman Empress]]; [[German Queen]];
[[List of Hungarian consorts|Queen consort of Hungary]] and [[List of Bohemian consorts|Bohemia]];
[[List of Austrian consorts|Archduchess consort of Austria]] | titles = | image = Diego Velázquez - Maria Anna of Spain - Prado.jpg | caption = ''[[Portrait of Maria Anna]]'' by Velazquez, 1630 | coronation = | reign = 15 February 1637 – 13 May 1646 | spouse = [[Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor]] | issue = [[Ferdinand IV, King of the Romans]]
[[Mariana of Austria|Mariana, Queen of Spain]]
[[Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor]] | full name = {{lang-es|María Ana de Austria y Austria}} | house = [[House of Habsburg|Habsburg]] | royal anthem = | father = [[Philip III of Spain]] | mother = [[Margaret of Austria (1584-1611)|Margaret of Austria]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|1606|8|18|df=y}} | birth_place = [[El Escorial]], [[Habsburg Spain|Spain]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1646|5|13|1606|8|18|df=y}} | death_place = [[Linz]], [[Archduchy of Austria|Austria]] | buried = [[Imperial Crypt]], [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | religion = [[Roman Catholicism]] }} {{House of Habsburg (Spain)}} '''[[Infanta]]''' '''Maria Anna of Spain''' (18 August 1606 – 13 May 1646)[https://books.google.com.pe/books/about/Handbuch_Der_Praktischen_Genealogie.html?id=1f-Nhuzfc5gC&redir_esc=y Eduard Heydenreich: ''Handbuch Der Praktischen Genealogie'', p. 52, BoD – Books on Demand 2012 - 448 p.] [retrieved 01 November 2016]. was a Holy Roman Empress and Queen of Hungary and Bohemia by marriage to [[Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor]].{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/204521/Ferdinand-III|title=Ferdinand III|work=Encyclopædia Britannica}} She acted as regent on several occasions during the absences of her spouse. Daughter of King [[Philip III of Spain]] and [[Margaret of Austria (1584-1611)|Margaret of Austria]], prior to her Imperial marriage she was considered a possible wife for [[Charles I of England|Charles, Prince of Wales]]; the event, later known in history as the "[[Spanish Match]]", provoked a domestic and political crisis in the Kingdoms of England and Scotland. In the imperial court in Vienna she continued to be strongly influenced by her native Spanish culture (from clothes to music) and also to promote the strengthening of relations between the Imperial and Spanish branches of the [[House of Habsburg]]. == Life == === Early years === Infanta Maria Anna of Spain was born in the Palace of [[El Escorial]], near [[Madrid]], on 18 August 1606 as the fourth child and third (but second surviving) daughter of King [[Philip III of Spain]] and his wife [[Margaret of Austria, Queen of Spain|Margaret of Austria]], Archduchess of the Inner Austrian branch of the House of Habsburg. Of her seven siblings, only four survived infancy: [[Anne of Austria|Anna]] (later wife of King [[Louis XIII of France]]), [[Philip IV of Spain]], [[Infante Carlos of Spain (1607–1632)|Charles]] (who died young in 1632) and [[Cardinal-Infante Ferdinand of Austria|Ferdinand]] (the later known Cardinal-Infante and [[List of governors of the Habsburg Netherlands|Governor of the Spanish Netherlands]]).{{cite book|first=Darryl |last=Lundy |date=5 March 2007 |title=Felipe III von Habsburg, Rey de España |publisher=ThePeerage.Com |url=http://thepeerage.com/p10278.htm#i102774}} cites {{cite book |first=Jirí |last=Louda |first2=Michael |last2=MacLagan |title=Lines of Succession: Heraldry of the Royal Families of Europe |edition= 2nd |location=London, U.K. |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |year=1999 |at=table 49}} {{cite book |first=Marcellus |last=von Redlich|title=Pedigrees of Some of the Emperor Charlemagne's Descendants, volume I |edition= 2nd |location=Baltimore, Maryland, U.S.A. |publisher= Genealogical Publishing Company |year=1999 |at=page 58}} Maria Anna's parents had a close kinship: her father was her mother's first cousin once-removed. On her father's side she was the granddaughter of King [[Philip II of Spain]], and his fourth wife and niece [[Anna of Austria, Queen of Spain|Archduchess Anne of Austria]], and on her mother's side she was the granddaughter of [[Charles II, Archduke of Austria|Charles II, Archduke of Inner Austria]] and his wife [[Maria Anna of Bavaria (1551–1608)|Princess Maria Anna of Bavaria]].{{cite book|first=Darryl |last=Lundy |date=7 March 2007 |title=Maria Anna von Habsburg, Infanta de España |publisher=ThePeerage.Com |url=http://thepeerage.com/p10306.htm#i103057}} cites {{cite book |first=Jirí |last=Louda |first2=Michael |last2=MacLagan |title=Lines of Succession: Heraldry of the Royal Families of Europe |edition= 2nd |location=London, U.K. |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |year=1999 |at=table 80}} From early childhood, Maria Anna has played an important role in the matrimonial projects of her father. In adolescence she was betrothed to Archduke John-Charles, eldest son and heir of [[Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor]] and his first wife [[Maria Anna of Bavaria (1574–1616)|Maria Anna of Bavaria]]; however, the marriage never took place due to Archduke John-Charles' early death in 1618.[https://books.google.com.pe/books?id=7_pmAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA519&lpg=PA519&dq=Prinzessin+Maria+Anna+von+Spanien+mit+Johann+Karl,&source=bl&ots=lhc8QJ2Plk&sig=zPIU9Vp2s9j3d-dVs8CcP9zMWXQ&hl=ru&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1_8r29PPOAhWEDpoKHdF0Bh8Q6AEIXzAP#v=onepage&q=Prinzessin%20Maria%20Anna%20von%20Spanien%20mit%20Johann%20Karl%2C&f=false Ludwig Albrecht Gebhardi: Genealogische Geschichte der erblichen Reichsstände in Teutschland; Halle: Johann Jacob Gebauer, 1779, vol. II, p. 519.] [retrieved 01 November 2016]. In 1622, King [[James VI and I|James I of England]] received an offer from the Spanish King Philip IV to strengthen the relations of their countries through a dynastic marriage between Charles, Prince of Wales, and Infanta Maria Anna. [[London]] and [[Madrid]] began active negotiations. The possible marriage between the Prince of Wales and the Spanish Infanta, was known in history under the name "[[Spanish Match]]", and caused an internal political crisis in both England and Scotland. In 1623 the Prince of Wales, accompanied by [[George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham]], visited Madrid to meet his intended bride.{{BLKO |wstitle=Habsburg, Maria Anna von Spanien |volume=7 |page=23}} However, Maria Anna did not wish to marry a Protestant and Charles would not convert to Catholicism. At the end, the wedding never took place not only for political reasons but also because of the reluctance of the new Spanish King to conclude a dynastic marriage with the [[House of Stuart]].[https://www.academia.edu/11072009/Dos_infantas_espan_olas_en_la_corte_imperial Beatrix Bastl, Jose Luis Colomer: ''Dos infantas españolas en la corte imperial''] [retrieved 01 November 2016].[https://books.google.com.pe/books?id=h2v69fUCDxYC&pg=PA73&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false Pauline Gregg: ''King Charles I'' - The Spanish Match, pp. 72–89.] [retrieved 01 November 2016].Braun, Keller, Schnettger 2016, p. 144.Hengerer 2012, p. 57. Charles eventually married [[Henrietta Maria of France]]. === Marriage === At the end of 1626 Maria Anna was betrothed to the younger brother of her first fiancé, [[Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand]], new heir of Emperor Ferdinand II. The formal engagement was preceded by a series of negotiations which were conducted in 1625. That same year, Prince Ferdinand was crowned [[King of Hungary]], and in 1627 [[King of Bohemia]]. In the negotiations were included all the life aspects of the Infanta at the court of her future spouse. Despite the desire of the groom that Maria Anna's confessor would be the [[Jesuit]] Ambrosio Penalosa, the appointment eventually went to [[Order of Friars Minor Capuchin|Capuchin]] Diego Quiroga. In the marriage contract signed by both parties in 1628, it was noted that Maria Anna could retain her rights of inheritance over the Spanish throne, while her older sister Infanta Anna, married to King Louis XIII of France in 1615, was forced to renounce to her rights.Hengerer 2012, p. 57, 64. Maria Anna had left Madrid for Vienna in December 1629. The travel took more than a year. En route by sea, in [[Genoa]] complications arose due to an epidemic of the [[Plague (disease)|plague]] that erupted in the [[Italian Peninsula]]. For this reason, the cortege was unable to stop in [[Bologna]], where [[Cardinal (Catholic Church)|Cardinal]] [[Antonio Barberini]] (nephew of [[Pope Urban VIII]]), was waiting for the Infanta to give her the [[Golden Rose]]. The cortege moved to [[Naples]], where Maria Anna finally received the award. Leaving the [[Kingdom of Naples]], the Infanta crossed the [[Papal States]], having made a [[pilgrimage]] to the [[Basilica della Santa Casa]]. On this section of her journey Maria Anna was accompanied by Roman aristocracy, led by another nephew of Pope Urban VIII, [[Taddeo Barberini]], [[Palestrina|Prince of Palestrina]]. On 26 January 1631 she arrived in [[Trieste]], where she met [[Archduke Leopold Wilhelm of Austria]], her future brother-in-law, who escort the Infanta to the Vienna court.[http://dspace.unitus.it/bitstream/2067/2542/1/fquatrini_tesid.pdf Francesca Quatrini: ''Eleonora d’Austria, Maria Anna d’Asburgo-Spagna e Maria Ludovica Gonzaga Nevers – tre regine in viaggio nell’Europa moderna. Sigla del settore scientifico-disciplinare''] [retrieved 01 November 2016].Hengerer 2012, p. 85. That day, Maria Anna was married to King Ferdinand of Hungria-Bohemia [[Proxy marriage|''per procura'']] with Archduke Leopold Wilhelm serving as the proxy. Before the official wedding, King Ferdinand, not trusting the previous portraits that he had seen of the Infanta, decided to secretly watch his bride. The Royal ''oberhofmeister'' asked for an audience with Maria Anna; on this visit, he was accompanied by some nobles, among whom was her groom. Struck by the beauty of the Infanta, King Ferdinand immediately revealed his identity and began a conversation with Maria Anna in Spanish.Hengerer 2012, pp. 85–86. The love and respect that the future emperor felt for his wife lasted through all their marriage. He was never unfaithful to her or had illegitimate children.Hengerer 2012, pp. 130–131. In [[Vienna]] on 20 February 1631 Maria Anna was formally married with King Ferdinand of Hungary-Bohemia, with festivities lasting a month. The marriage was described as friendly. Maria Anna was described as happy-tempered, friendly, and intelligent, and she able to ease the feelings of the melancholic Ferdinand. ===Holy Roman Empress and German Queen === With Maria Anna, arrived at the Imperial court in Vienna the Spanish fashion, theater, dance and music (including the first sounded [[guitar]]). As the wife of the heir, she maintained good relations with all the members of her husband's family; however, she had a complicated relationship with Ferdinand's stepmother, Empress [[Eleonora Gonzaga (1598–1655)|Eleonora Gonzaga]], mainly because between both began a competition for influence at the Imperial court. Maria Anna also paid much attention to the arts, especially painting. She collected works of Italian, Spanish and Flemish painters of the late [[Renaissance]] and early [[Baroque]].Braun, Keller, Schnettger 2016, pp. 146–148. In [[Regensburg]] on 22 December 1636 Ferdinand was elected [[King of the Romans]], and a week later he was crowned by the [[Archbishop of Mainz]]. Maria Anna was crowned Queen of Germany one month later, on 21 January 1637. After his father's death on 15 February 1637, Ferdinand became Holy Roman Emperor under the name of Ferdinand III and sovereign King of Hungary and Bohemia. After him, his wife received the titles of Holy Roman Empress and sovereign Queen. Her coronation as Queen of Hungary took place in [[Pressburg]] during the [[Diet of Hungary|Hungarian Diet]] of 1637–1638.Hengerer 2012, p. 172.[https://books.google.com.pe/books?id=IacaBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA315&dq=Maria+Anna+of+Spain+1606+-+1646&hl=ru&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj81JC1k_bOAhVCD5oKHWYgDHgQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=Maria%20Anna%20of%20Spain%201606%20-%201646&f=false R. Bireley: ''Ferdinand II, Counter-Reformation Emperor, 1578 — 1637''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 2014, p. 302] {{ISBN|978-1-10-706715-8}}. Maria Anna, being active politically as the adviser of her spouse, was an important mediator between the Emperor and their Spanish relatives. Despite the fact that she always defended the interests of her husband, she didn't forget the interests of her brothers King Philip IV and the Cardinal-Infante.Braun, Keller, Schnettger 2016, p. 152. In her court, which was consisted mainly of Spaniards, frequent guests were the Spanish ambassador and diplomats. The Emperor, during his absences from the imperial court in Vienna, appointed his wife as [[regent]], for example in 1645 during the [[Thirty Years' War]], when he was in the Kingdom of Bohemia. === Death === In March 1645 Maria Anna and her children left [[Linz]], due to the approach of the Protestant Swedish army, and moved to [[Vienna]]. By April it was ready to cross the [[Danube]] there and threatened to occupy the city. The Imperial family fled instead temporarily to [[Graz]].Hengerer 2012, pp. 230–231. After returning to Vienna, they were forced to move again to Linz because of the plague. The Empress' sixth pregnancy became known in January 1646; four months later, on 12 May at Linz Castle, Maria Anna suddenly felt ill with fever and heavy bleeding and died the next morning. Her unborn child, a girl, was taken out alive from her womb. She was named Maria after her mother, but only lived a few hours. On 24 May both mother and daughter in the same coffin were moved to Vienna and buried in the [[Imperial Crypt]], which already contained the coffins with the remains of the two sons of the Empress who died earlier. The funeral cortege was accompanied by the Spanish ambassador and the Empress' maid of honor. Very upset by the death of his wife and child, the Emperor was unable to attend the funeral.Hengerer 2012, p. 247.Braun, Keller, Schnettger 2016, pp. 141–142. However, after returning to Vienna in late August he finally paid his respects to the remains of Maria Anna, and in September he announced the engagement of their eldest daughter Maria Anna with [[Balthasar Charles, Prince of Asturias]]. However, the Prince died the following month shortly after the announcement. It should be noted that the Spaniards courtiers members of the late Empress' household who came with her from Spain, including her confessor and the maids of honor of the late Empress, stayed at the Imperial court in Vienna and lived there for a few more years after her death.Hengerer 2012, p. 249. ==Issue== During her marriage, Maria Anna gave birth to six children:[http://www.habsburger.net/de/kapitel/ferdinand-iii-ehen-und-nachkommen Martin Mutschlechner: ''Ferdinand III – Ehen und Nachkommen''] [retrieved 01 November 2016]. * [[Ferdinand IV, King of the Romans|Ferdinand IV]] (8 September 1633 – 9 July 1654), [[King of the Romans]] and titular King of Hungary and Bohemia. * [[Mariana of Austria|Maria Anna]] (22 December 1634 – 16 May 1696), who married her maternal uncle King [[Philip IV of Spain]]. * Philip August (15 July 1637 – 22 June 1639), Archduke of Austria. * Maximilian Thomas (21 December 1638 – 29 June 1639), Archduke of Austria. * [[Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor]] (9 June 1640 – 5 May 1705). * Maria (born and died 13 May 1646), Archduchess of Austria. == Ancestors == {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center | boxstyle_1 = background-color: #fcc; | boxstyle_2 = background-color: #fb9; | boxstyle_3 = background-color: #ffc; | boxstyle_4 = background-color: #bfc; | boxstyle_5 = background-color: #9fe; | 1 = 1. '''Maria Anna of Austria''' | 2 = 2. [[Philip III of Spain]] | 3 = 3. [[Margaret of Austria, Queen of Spain|Margaret of Austria]] | 4 = 4. [[Philip II of Spain]]{{BLKO |wstitle=Habsburg, Philipp III. |volume=7 |page=120}} | 5 = 5. [[Anna of Austria (1549-1580)|Anna of Austria]] (≠ 15) | 6 = 6. [[Isabella of Portugal]] (= 23) | 10 = 10. [[Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor]]{{BLKO |wstitle=Habsburg, Anna von Oesterreich (Königin von Spanien) |volume=6 |page=151}} | 11 = 11. [[Anne of Bohemia and Hungary]] (= 13, 21) }} == Depictions in art == [[Claire Jowitt|Jowitt]] views the character of princess Donusa in [[Philip Massinger|Massinger]]'s 1624 play ''[[The Renegado]]'' as an allegory of the Infanta during the failed marriage attempt.Jowitt, C. (2004); ''Massinger's ''The Renegado'' (1624) and the Spanish marriage'', ''[[Cahiers Elisabethains]]'', 65, p 45–53 In 1634, the Spanish poet and playwright [[Pedro Calderón de la Barca]], in honor of the victory of the Spaniards and Austrians over the Swedes in the [[Battle of Nördlingen (1634)|Battle of Nördlingen]], set in Madrid a performance in which Maria Anna with her husband was one of the actors.Hengerer 2012, p. 107. Save a few portraits of Maria Anna as child, almost all of them are included in the collection of the [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]] in [[Vienna]]. In the earliest of these paintings, made by [[Juan Pantoja de la Cruz]], she is shown at one year of age.[https://www.khm.at/objektdb/detail/2316/?offset=3&lv=list&cHash=30954a69b0a9bb303f1c032cc24eac5b ''Infantin Maria Anna (1606-1646), Kaiserin, im Alter von 4 bis 5 Monaten, Bildnis in ganzer Figur'' in: www.khm.at] [retrieved 01 November 2016]. A portrait of the Infanta Maria Anna, then Queen of Hungary and Bohemia, made by [[Diego Velázquez]], court painter at Madrid, was part of the collection of the [[Museo del Prado]].[https://www.museodelprado.es/coleccion/obra-de-arte/doa-maria-de-austria-reina-de-hungria/1e61408f-ef2d-498b-a719-289a1fbd91ff ''Doña María de Austria, reina de Hungría'' in: www.museodelprado.es] [retrieved 01 November 2016]. Portraits of the Empress made by [[Frans Luycx]] (painter at the court in Vienna), [[Bartolomé González y Serrano]], [[Rodrigo de Villandrando (painter)|Rodrigo de Villandrando]], [[Justus Sustermans]], [[Juan van der Hamen]] and other unknown authors are also stored in the collections of the Kunsthistorisches Museum,[https://www.khm.at/objektdb/?query=all_persons%3AKaiserin%20Maria%20Anna%20Tochter%20des%20Philipp%20III.%20von%20Habsburg%20Spanien ''Die Habsburger — Maria Anna von Spanien, Kaiserin'' in: www.khm.at] [retrieved 01 November 2016]. Museo del Prado,[https://www.museodelprado.es/coleccion/obras-de-arte?search=do%C3%B1a%20mar%C3%ADa%20de%20austria,%20reina%20de%20hungr%C3%ADa ''Doña María Ana de Austria, reina de Hungría'' in: www.museodelprado.es] [retrieved 01 November 2016]. the gallery of the [[Schloss Esterházy]] in [[Eisenstadt]][http://esterhazy.at/layout/esterhazy/files/Bilderwelten%20Paul%20I%20Esterhazy.pdf ''Ez világ, mint egy kert...'' in: esterhazy.at] [retrieved 01 November 2016]. and the [[Musée Fesch]] in [[Ajaccio]].[http://spanishbaroqueart.tumblr.com/page/6 ''Spanish Baroque Art'' in: www.spanishbaroqueart.com] [retrieved 01 November 2016]. Image:Juan Pantoja de la Cruz 006.jpg|'''''Infantin Maria Anna, Kaiserin, im Alter von 4 bis 5 Monaten, Bildnis in ganzer Figur''''' (1607), by [[Juan Pantoja de la Cruz]], [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]], [[Vienna]]. Image:Maria Anna, Infanta of Spain, future Holy Roman Empress by Bartolomé González, c. 1608-1610.jpg|'''''Maria Anna, Infanta of Spain, Later Archduchess of Austria, Queen of Hungary and Empress, as a child''''', by [[Bartolomé González y Serrano]], National Trust, Cliveden. Image:Bartolomé González y Serrano 006.jpg|'''''Infantin Maria Anna, Kaiserin, in ganzer Figur''''' (1617), by [[Bartolomé González y Serrano]], [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]], [[Vienna]]. Image:Luycks-maria reina de hungria-prado.jpg|'''''María de Austria, reina de Hungría''''' (1635), by [[Frans Luycx]], [[Museo del Prado]], [[Madrid]]. Image:Juan van der Hamen y León - Infanta María de Austria.jpg|'''''María Ana de Austria''''' (c. 1630), by [[Juan van der Hamen]], [[Musée Fesch]], [[Ajaccio]]. Image:FerdinandIII.MariaAnna.JPG|'''''Ölgemälde von Ferdinand III. von Habsburg und seiner ersten Gemahlin Maria Anna von Spanien''''' (1628/30) by [[Justus Sustermans]], [[Schloss Esterházy]], [[Eisenstadt]]. Image:Maria Anna of Austria, Holy Roman Empress with her son Archduke Ferdinand by an unknown artist.jpg|'''''Infantin Maria Anna, Kaiserin, in ganzer Figur mit ihrem erstgeborenen Sohn Ferdinand''''' (1634), Anonymous, [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]], [[Vienna]]. == Notes == {{reflist|2}} == References == * [https://books.google.com.pe/books?id=MpdVDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA117&lpg=PA117&dq=imperatrice+Eleonora+Gonzaga+1598+-+1655&source=bl&ots=85GwZlCe34&sig=bFpM_Gdhf8Wp_mYNMKg5RQfN-Bo&hl=ru&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj58bmSk5HOAhVECpoKHQTVBiAQ6AEISDAM#v=onepage&q=imperatrice%20Eleonora%20Gonzaga%201598%20-%201655&f=false Bettina Braun, Katrin Keller, Matthias Schnettger: ''Nur die Frau des Kaisers?: Kaiserinnen in der Frühen Neuzeit''], Böhlau ed., Vienna 2016 {{ISBN|978-3-20-520085-7}}. * [http://www.boehlau-verlag.com/download/160420/978-3-205-77765-6_OpenAccess.pdf M. Hengerer: ''Kaiser Ferdinand III. (1608—1657). Eine Biographie''], Böhlau ed., Vienna, Köln, Weimar 2012 {{ISBN|978-3-205-77765-6}}. * [http://www.literature.at/viewer.alo?objid=11810&page=28&scale=3.33&viewmode=fullscreen Habsburg, Maria Anna von Spanien], Biographisches Lexikon des Kaiserthums Oesterreich, Vienna Kaiserlich-königliche Hof- und Staatsdruckerei, p. 52 – 458 p. == External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051121014048/http://worldroots.com/brigitte/royal/bio/mariaaustriabio1606.html Worldroots.com] *{{Commons-inline|Category:Maria Anna of Spain|Maria Anna of Spain}} {{s-start}} {{s-hou|[[House of Habsburg]]|18 August|1606|13 May|1646}} {{s-roy}} {{s-break}} {{s-bef|rows=2|before=[[Eleonore Gonzaga]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Empress of the Holy Roman Empire]]

{{Infobox person | name = Naomi Miller | image = | image_size = | birth_place = | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | disappeared_date = 2005 | disappeared_place = [[Texas]] | death_date = 2005 (aged 34) | death_place = found buried underneath the [[San Angelo]] speedway on March 8, 2017 | children = 2 }} '''Naomi Michelle Miller''' was a woman who disappeared in 2005, and was found buried underneath the old San Angelo speedway<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ktxs.com/news/missing-womans-remains-found-buried-at-former-san-angelo-speedway-husband-charged-with-murder/384762982|title=Remains of missing woman found buried at old San Angelo Speedway|last=Burch|first=Jamie|date=2017-03-09|work=KTXS|access-date=2017-05-15|language=en-US}}</ref> on March 8, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://conexionsanangelo.com/police/2574-possible-accomplice-to-naomi-miller-s-murder-arrested|title=Possible accomplice to Naomi Miller's Murder, arrested|last=Garcia|first=Juan|access-date=2017-05-22|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812072622/http://conexionsanangelo.com/police/2574-possible-accomplice-to-naomi-miller-s-murder-arrested#|archive-date=2017-08-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Disappearance== Miller went missing in 2005, but was not reported missing until December 2015. Her relatives have said that she "just took off" after a family fight one night which Tom Green County Sheriff David Jones during a press conference with local media, and also stated that none of her personal or banking records indicated any activity.<ref name=star>{{Cite news|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/news/state/texas/article137588718.html|title=Missing for 11 years, West Texas woman found buried behind old racetrack|work=star-telegram|access-date=2017-05-21|language=en}}</ref>
==Investigation and aftermath== The first suspect in the death of Miller was her ex-husband Robert Miller,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sanangelolive.com/news/crime/2017-03-14/sheriff-arrests-likely-accomplice-murder-naomi-michelle-miller|title=Sheriff Arrests Likely Accomplice for Murder of Naomi Michelle Miller|date=2017-03-14|work=San Angelo LIVE!|access-date=2017-05-21|language=en-US}}</ref> and the police have also arrested a second suspect in the death of Miller named Ludonna Gail Yoder who is the girlfriend of Robert Miller who said that she disposed of Miller's body the night that she was murdered in a shallow [[grave]] at Miller's ex house on which was in Tom Green community.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/crime/2017/03/14/second-murder-suspected-arrested-millers-death/99172562/|title=Second murder suspected arrested in Miller's death|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2017-05-15|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fox15abilene.com/news/local/san-angelo/new-court-documents-detail-ludonna-yoders-role-in-miller-murder/422601511|title=New Court Documents Detail LuDonna Yoder's Role in Miller Murder|last=TEGNA|work=KXVA|access-date=2017-05-21|language=en-US}}</ref> Miller's parents were contacted about her murder in 2005.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/2017/03/10/details-investigation-emerge-complaint/99004400/|title=Details in murder investigation emerge from affidavit|work=Detroit Free Press|access-date=2017-05-22|language=en}}</ref> Her ex-husband Robert had faced charges in her death,<ref name=star/> and both he and his current wife named LuDonna Miller also known as LuDonna Gail Yoder pleaded guilty and were sentenced to 38 years in prison.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gosanangelo.com/story/news/crime/2018/07/16/yoder-pleads-guilty-murder-woman-found-san-angelo-speedway/789584002/|title=Woman pleads guilty to murdering Naomi Miller found buried at San Angelo race track|work=San Angelo|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en}}</ref>
